title: rees mogg matt hancock rosena allin khan coronavirus labour doctor
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.'She is on the frontline of the Covid crisis and deserves an apology,' says Labour's shadow Commons leaderJacob Rees-Mogg has defended Matt Hancock, saying he will not ask the health secretary to apologise for telling a Labour frontbencher and frontline NHS worker to consider her tone”.The shadow Commons leader, Valerie Vaz, demanded the cabinet minister apologise to Rosena Allin-Khan, in the wake of considerable criticism for his remarks during a debate on the government’s failings on Covid-19.Ms Allin-Khan, who has been working as an A&ampE doctor during the crisis, told MPs the minister’s testing strategy was “non-existent”, adding: “Community testing was scrapped, mass testing was slow to roll-out and testing figures are now being manipulated.”Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesShe added on Tuesday that many frontline NHS staff believed the government’s lack of testing had “cost lives and is responsible for many families being unnecessarily torn apart by grief”.Mr Hancock, who was in the Commons to answer an urgent question from the shadow health secretary, Jonathan Ashworth, replied “I welcome the honourable lady to her post as part of the shadow health team. I think she might do well to take a leaf out of the shadow health secretary’s book in terms of tone”.Created with Sketch.How coronavirus lockdowns changed the world's most polluted cities Show all 6Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Later, Ms Allin-Khan posted on Twitter she would not “watch her tone” when challenging the government at the despatch box.Responding to the comments on Wednesday, Ms Vaz said: “How many times have people from the BAME community and women hear that remark?”“And to compare her to a white male – almost telling her to behave in the same way as a white male – is totally unacceptable. I’d be grateful if the leader could ask him to apologise. She is on the frontline of the Covid crisis and deserves an apology.”But in response Jacob Rees-Mogg, the leader of the Commons, said the health secretary was doing a “magnificent job” and that “we are very lucky to have someone who has shown such personal commitment” during the coronavirus pandemic.“Therefore, I’m not going to ask him to apologise,” he added. “I’m going to say in the cut and thrust of debate people are entitled to say things and that is perfectly legitimate.”The latest news on Brexit, politics and beyond direct to your inboxEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive updates on politics every morning by emailDuring business questions, Ms Vaz also requested that Sir Keir Starmer be briefed on Boris Johnson’s plans to ease the lockdown in an anticipated address to the nation on Sunday evening.“Could I ask that the leader of the opposition has sight, under Privy Council rules, the strategy the government is going to set out on Sunday,” she said.Mr Rees-Mogg replied: “It’s not for me to promise briefings outside the House – it’s not my responsibility, but I think the good will and the positive contribution that has been made is very important.”He also defended the prime minister’s decision to announce any changes to the current coronavirus restrictions directly to the public on Sunday – rather than the House of Commons.The senior Tory added the government will provide the opportunity on Monday for MPs to scrutinise No 10’s approach.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful when making a comment and adhere to our CommunityYou may not agree with our views, or other users’, but please respond to them respectfullySwearing, personal abuse, racism, sexism, homophobia and other discriminatory or incitefulDo not impersonate other users or reveal private information about third partiesWe reserve the right to delete inappropriate posts and ban offending users without notificationYou can find our Community Guidelines in full here.Create a commenting name to join the debateOnly letters and numbers acceptedFollow replies to this article --Follow replies to my comment --There are no comments yet - title: california uber lyft sue gig workers employees law
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Ride-hailing firms are ignoring new law on gig workers, says state attorney generalCalifornia plans to sue Uber and Lyft, the state attorney general said on Tuesday, arguing the companies have failed to abide by a landmark law that would reclassify many gig workers as employees.Xavier Becerra, the attorney general,&nbspannounced the state's plans, saying the ride-hail companies were allegedly engaged in “misclassifying hundreds of thousands of drivers, depriving them of worker protections and access to safety net programmes” under the new law, which went into effect in January.The law prescribes a three-prong test to establish a worker is an independent contractor, including demonstrating the worker is free from a company's control, is performing a function outside of its core business and already performs such work independently.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesUber spokesperson Matthew Wing said the company plans to contest the matter in court. “At a time when California's economy is in crisis with four million people out of work, we need to make it easier, not harder, for people to quickly start earning,” he said in a statement.Lyft company spokesperson CJ&nbspMacklin said in a statement:&nbsp“We are looking forward to working with the attorney general and mayors across the state to bring all the benefits of California's innovation economy to as many workers as possible, especially during this time when the creation of good jobs with access to affordable health care and other benefits is more important than ever.”Created with Sketch.World news in pictures Show all 50Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Created with Sketch.Bride Janine runs over to her wedding at a Drive-in cinema in Duesseldorf, Germany. title: how to stop glasses fogging face mask tips see
story: Subscribe nowLog in using your social network accountLog in directly with The IndependentKeep me logged inForgotten your password?Want an ad-free experience?Subscribe to Independent Premium.Use polycarbonate lenses, wash them with soapy water, and ‘double-cross’ tie your face masksThe White House coronavirus taskforce has begun winding down but science has begun ramping up a “mask-force” of experts to dispel conspiracy theories on the vaccine to mask fog, like duct taping your face to create an air-tight seal.Trauma doctors Sheraz Shafi Malik and Shahbaz Shafi Malik write that the misting effect is not just a nuisance, the annoying phenomenon could even incapacitate a person.Sharing the full story, not just the headlinesTheir emergency room-tested, peer-reviewed method is as follows:Step 1: Immediately before wearing a face mask, wash the spectacles with soapy waterStep 2: Shake off the excessStep 3: Let the spectacles air dry, or gently dry off lenses with a soft tissueStep 4: Put them back onWhile the solution is seemingly simple enough, the misting scourge is anything but. In their paper, The misting characteristics of spectacle lenses, researchers Tom H&nbspMargrain and Chris Owen tested crown glass, CR39 and polycarbonate materials found not all spectacle lenses are created equal.“Both the physical properties of the spectacle lens and a number of environmental factors determine how long spectacles take to demist,” they write.“The polycarbonate lens demisted more rapidly than the CR39 lens which, in turn, demisted more rapidly than the glass lens. This indicates that polycarbonate spectacle lenses should be used in conditions where the adverse effects of spectacle misting need to be minimised.”When can we really expect coronavirus to end?Everything you need to know on supermarket delivery slotsThe dirty truth about washing your handsWhich countries around the world has coronavirus spread to?Listen to the latest episode of The Independent Coronavirus PodcastBut as spectacles are only one part of the problem, they are only one part of the solution.The researchers showed how face masks direct much of the exhaled air upwards towards the spectacle lenses, and the misting occurs from the warm water vapour condensing on the cooler surface of the lens.As a result, tiny droplets form due to the surface tension between water molecules. The droplets scatter the light and reduce the ability of the lenses to transmit contrast.No hype, just the advice and analysis you needEnter your email addressFill out this fieldEmail already exists. Log in to update your newsletter preferencesRegister with your social account or click&nbsphere to log inI would like to receive morning headlines Monday - Friday plus breaking news alerts by emailThe soapy water leaves behind a thin surfactant film that reduces this surface tension and causes the water molecules to evenly spread out into a transparent layer.“This ‘surfactant effect’ is widely utilised to prevent misting of surfaces in many everyday situations,” the doctors Malik write.But what if the misting process could be interrupted at the level of transmission?In their paper Tying a surgical mask to prevent fogging, researchers DJ Jordan and R Pritchard-Jones argue that the problem of “fogging” results in reduced visual acuity.While a standard method of tying a mask involves knotting two ties so they lie above and below the ear in a near parallel appearance, their method consists of looping the bottom tie above the ear and the top tie below the ear.“This approach allows a closer seal over the nose and along the infraorbital ridge, stopping venting at the superior part of the facemask, and forms two lateral ‘vents’, allowing exhaled air to escape away,” they write.“Multiple attempts have been made to solve this problem, including washing prior to application, adding tape, or the use of several masks, but we believe this to be the first description of a novel method that does not involve any further cost or instrumentation.”The takeaway from today’s coronavirus mask-force briefing experts advise people use polycarbonate lenses, wash them with soapy water, and double-cross tie face masks to avoid the loss of visual acuity and incapacitation from foggy goggles.Share your thoughts and debate the big issuesJoin the discussionPlease be respectful title: pub beer gardens social distance coronavirus
story: Professor Robert Dingwall has said it is time to relax the strict lockdown rules that came in force on March .He told BBC Radio s Today programme on Friday: If it is a sunny weekend afternoon and the pub has a garden and the landlords are prepared to accept responsibility for not overcrowding that garden, I see no particular reason why it should not reopen.The sociologist, who is a member of the New and Emerging Respiratory Virus Threats Advisory Group, also claimed the two-metre social distancing rule was conjured up out of nowhere.He said: Theres never been a scientic basis for two metres, its kind of a rule of thumb. But its not like there is …rigorous scientic literature that it is founded upon.The UK went into lockdown in March as clubs and bars were ordered to shut until the foreseeable future.Police were used to enforce the shutdown as they were granted power under the Anti-social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act  in order revoke operating licences for dferent types of venuesthey werent following the Governments measures.Prime Minister Boris Johnson ordered all pubs, clubs, theatres, cinemas, gyms and sport centres to shut as soon as they reasonably can and not to reopen - as hundreds were seen across the country sinking their final pints.Last week it emerged that pubs would be the last to reopen.a government source claimed to the Daily Mail that one plan is to lt the lockdown in phases.Under the possible plans, outdoor spaces would be opened first while pubs would be last.The best case scenario could see restrictions eased for non-essential shops from early to mid-May.The guidelines could again be relaxed by June and July - allowing for pubs and restaurants to reopen  by the end of summer.There has been growing pressure on the government to outline its plan, with economic paralysis wreaking havoc on jobs and businesses.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. title: journalists coronavirus pandemic lockdown save press
story: Nonetheless, there is one indisputable need this crisis has highlighted like no other - the value of journalism. British journalism, in particular.What’s stopping you right now from falling off your perch in fits of laughter  Well, the fact that you’re currently digesting a work of journalism.This probably means that it’s an act – let’s call it that for now – which you’re used to committing on a fairly regular basis.Let’s also assume then that much of the information you gather, store and share comes from such journalistic sources.It’s likely you frequently form opinions and make decisions based on this content you consume.In fact, think really hard for a moment and try and imagine an area of your le where you haven’t been guided in some form by journalism.Buying a house, investing your savings, choosing a school, picking a holiday, deciding which box to put your cross in when you go into a polling booth .If you’re honest with yourself, you tend to make most of those decisions after you’ve digested the array of journalism available to you. And let’s also admit, disregarded too.Some of it is opinion led, some is impartial. You might not agree with all of it, and sometimes you might get ruddy cross at a paper or commentator that doesn’t chime with your world view.But together, the many erse components of British journalism create something which is profoundly valuable.The Covid- pandemic has tested our society to the limit. In the midst of a national crisis, journalists have been putting their lives at risk to keep you informed.News outlets have faithfully broadcast public health announcements – but also held our political leaders to account.The Downing Street daily conference has become a household staple, with ministerial interrogation by the press corps regularly influencing government policy.Without such probing questions and front page splashes, would you have known about the dearth of PPE or the crisis in our care homes Journalism, from local to national level, has connected communities in a way that social networks can only dream of. We have celebrated triumph in the face of adversity – and also documented tributes from the tens of thousands who have lost loved ones.But now we come to the rub.With the country under lockdown, British journalism is facing the biggest threat in its storied history.For newspapers, sales have dramatically fallen. For broadcasters and online outlets, advertising has gone through the floor even whilst audience numbers have risen.Yes, journalism joins one of many industries in financial peril right now.The work of reporters should be held up to scrutiny like any other profession. But we also need to acknowledge the sacrices its practitioners are making to keep the public informed.Everything that journalism hands to you doesn’t come for free.I’m sure that when you think about this properly, in a way you might never have done before, it really is needed more than everWe have to safeguard journalism. It is far too important to discard because it isn’t worth contemplating what the world would look likequality journalism didn’t exist.I don’t need to urge you to buy a paper or take up an online subscription, but I want you to tell everyone you meet that our sector is under a very real and present threat.I am the CEO of the Journalists’ Charity. It was founded in  by Charles Dickens and a group of parliamentary reporters – naturally in a pub.Our core mission to this day remains the same: to bring aid to journalists and their dependents who have fallen on hard times.We are stepping up to the mark, helping those in need with emergency funding and practical and emotional support.It’s why we’ve launched a #supportjournalism campaign in print and on social media.For me, a lockdown without journalists would be unthinkable.That’s why the Journalists’ Charity is standing four-square behind our industry when it needs us most. But we also need you to do your bit too.The Journalists’ Charity has been helping journalists through tough times for more than  years. The charity is currently supporting iniduals from all sectors struggling from the impact of Coronavirus. title: joe wicks lockdown jamie oliver
story: RIGHT then, Joe Wicks. He’s just Jamie Oliver with a skipping rope, I assumed, before this wretched lockdown business began.A character we’ve all seen in our local park, with a pair of boxing gloves and a stopwatch, charging financial managers £ a haemorrhoid to do some sit-ups over by the ornamental lake.One of Britain’s ever-growing army of personal trainers who,he wasn’t bouncing around on YouTube every morning, would be clogging up Love Island or Ex On The Beach.That’s what I thought, anyway.Then the coronavirus hit, the local swimming pool shut, the man became a phenomenon and before I could come to my senses, Joe and his infernal timing device were beeping away in my living room, every morning, as I joined in his PE lesson. Inevitably, it didn’t last.First, Joe’s routine did me what I can only describe as “a mischief”.Then, one morning, aged , I caught sight of myself, in a picture frame, doing his “reverse frog shuffle” and thought: “Stuff this for type two diabetes. I’m out.”I’d got no closer to understanding Joe’s astonishing popularity, though, which is truly global.Over , people log in just to stare at his fairly spartan living room, every Monday to Friday.Hundreds of thousands more appear when Joe starts his  minutes of physical jerks.So, in an attempt to unlock the greatest mystery of the outbreak, I kept watching Joe and swtly came to the conclusion success was not linked to his presenting skills.But while they are helping save lives, who is there to help them The Sun has launched an appeal to raise £MILLION for NHS workers. The Who Cares Wins Appeal aims to get vital support to staff in their hour of need.We have teamed up with NHS Charities Together in their urgent Covid- Appeal to ensure the money gets to exactly who needs it.The Sun is donating £, and we would like YOU to help us raise a million pounds, to help THEM. No matter how little you can spare, please donate today here: www.thesun whocareswinsappeal.Because, for a host, he has a strangely distracted and chaotic air about him, with sessions regularly being interrupted by technical issues, forgetfulness and tiny daughter Indie, who charged in, dressed as Zog the dragon, on Friday.He’s not the greatest multitasker either, as Joe often demonstrates with the geography quiz he’s introduced to jolly things along.“What is the capital city of Moscow. . .   No. I mean Russia.”He also has to believe me when I tell him he’s not one of le’s natural comedians.“What’s the capital of Cuba  Fray Bentos. Nah, only joking.”The jokes need to go the same way as the viewers’ poems, in honour of Joe, which he was actually reading out loud, until modesty finally prevailed.Much safer ground is the “spot the dference” competition, which borders on insulting, when he’s merely placed his wall atlas upside down or swapped his electric guitar for a ukulele, but does hint at the drive, ambition and ego behind the man.One day he replaced the atlas with a picture of himself, the next with a picture of his “other house” in Los Angeles and suddenly the penny dropped.Joe’s loaded and his head is not just on its way to Hollywood, it’s already there, making movies and doing squat thrusts with Gwyneth and Brad.The weird thing is, in other presenters, soap actors or comedians, I’d roll my eyes at the folly.With Joe Wicks, I don’t. ’Cos I can’t help it, I quite like him.Part of that may be linked to his no-frills background and a level of personal generosity that’s way beyond most of us .But I like to think it’s got more to do with the fact that, at a time when other cynical, doom-mongering TV hosts are desperately trying to read the public mood, reinvent themselves and force their agenda on viewers, Joe Wicks is just doing what he’s always done. Sit-ups.He may not be Emily Maitlis , but he’s the irrepressible and lucky optimist telling us to get off our fat a***s when we need to hear it most.He’s temporarily indisposed at the moment, of course.A gammy arm means we Rosie is leading the workouts.But I was firmly of the opinion nothing and no one could ever stand in the way of world domination, until I tuned into Sunday night’s Diva On Lockdown and there was Gemma Collins trying to contort her mighty bulk into one of Joe’s squats while she bellowed: “I wonder how Joe Wicks would feelhe knew the GC was doing his workout ”Beaten, I’d imagine.He must never know.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.And her face is glued to the back of her head.So there will be hell to payit comes unstuck on The Real Marigold Hotel, where the only other one of the eight celebs who’s appeared looking as unearthly as Britt is former Dragons’ Den star Duncan Bannatyne, whose hair is now a “vibrant and colourful” shade of roast papaya orange. And will remain that way, until the monsoon breaks.It’s probably safe to say neither of them will be hanging around that long, though, or “retiring to India” any time soon.This is the fourth series of the BBC show and not one of the famous pensioners has given the place a second look yet.They have, however, all come home alive.So I wish the Beeb would count its lucky stars, cut the pretence, make Duncan pay for everyone’s holiday and let us all enjoy their discomfort, which is considerable and very entertaining.During the first episode: John “Nasty Nick” Altman proved as supple as Tower Bridge at his first ever yoga lesson.Paul Chuckle remained confined to barracks with the trots.Henry “Blowers” Blofeld rejected insect repellent on the grounds that: “Mosquitoes get p***edthey bite me.”And actress Susie Blake certainly didn’t hold back when the local foot doctor told her: “You have some unwanted growths.”“Yes, I have haemorrhoids.”Susie, too much inflammation.Jamie Redknapp: “We always used to turn up late but somehow we’d make it in time.Martin Keown: “Vieira was the best I ever played with. But Henry was a great player, so don’t make me choose between them.”Paul Merson: “The secret to working hard is to work hard.”ON one particularly fraught episode of her Channel  show, last week, Steph McGovern was forced to let a wasp out of her living room window, live on air.Probably halving her audience in the process.A day later it was announced the show itself was being released back into the wild, or as they put it “taking a break”.Credit for this development was being given to Steph’s long-suffering neighbours, who’d objected to the disruption the production had caused and may yet get a Bafta fellowship for their intervention.Truth be told, though, Steph’s “power hour of positivity” was more likely killed by worthiness, lack of content, technical issues and the host herself, who’s a rotten interviewer, kills every good joke stone dead, has the same set response to everythingand a terrible habit of asking exactly the wrong question.“Martin , what are you doing with all that toilet paper ” “Errr . . . ”There’s talk of a brave new dawn, in a shiny Leeds studio, later this year and when I last checked, author Marian Keyes was giving some pointed advice on how to become a good novelist: “Your first efforts will be woefully appalling. It’s like anything in le you want to be good at. Keep showing up.”Steph. Don’t.MORE now from Russell Grant’s “uncannily accurate”  predictions in December’s Mirror.“Scorpio — travel will be a great source of joy for you in April.”Yeah, April. How’d that work out for you Netflix thriller series Fauda. Channel ’s SAS: Who Dares Wins . Episode two of BBC’s Jewel Of Arabia .BBC repeating Bob Monkhouse: The Last Stand.And BBC Breakfast discovering that not only is he a war hero and charity giant, he’s a former Blankety Blank contestant as well.Cometh the hour, cometh Colonel Tom.Craig: “Arm.”Bradley Walsh: “What vowel precedes the name of more than ten dferent Apple products ”Becky: “C.”Tipping Point, Ben Shephard: “Which word used to describe horses of a reddish brown colour is also a type of window ”Paul: “Velux.”RE: The Chase, Bradley Walsh: “The name of what flightless bird is slang for someone who refuses to face facts ”Becky: “Kiwi.”You mock, but I shouted: “Diane Abbott.”Table, restaurant, postcode, country, Commonwealth of Nations and beyond that, his own gravitational field.Dumbest question was obviously: “Would you like dessert ”CHANNEL ’s When Will Lockdown End  The highlights.Professor Hugh Montgomery: “I don’t know.”Professor Graham Medley: “Anyone who tells you they know is lying.”Professor Peter Horby: “We just don’t know.”So in conclusion, try asking Russell Grant.RANDOM irritations: Have I Got News For You echoing to nothing but the sound of its own self-satisfied laughter.ITV numbskulls destroying Van Der Valk’s famous theme tune.Toxic hypocrite Frankie Boyle biting the Press hand that’s fed him far too well, by the looks of things.BBC’s Panorama failing to reveal every single interviewee on Has The Government Failed The NHS  was a left-wing activist.And ITV’s Joel Dommett making we Hannah the co-host of his Home Alone show.Which is a bit like Linda McCartney sharing lead vocals with Ringo. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: boris must ease lockdown soon
story: Boris Johnson cannot be sure the NHS would not be swamped by a second wave of infections.He has, though, taken out comprehensive insurance: The expansion of health service capacity was so huge that it can now afford to shut the new ,-bed Nightingale Hospital in London and place it on standby.The PM’s “unlockdown” decision was urgent even before the grim news of two million new benefit claims. Our formerly thriving economy is on its knees, losing billions a day. Huge numbers of jobs have been lost, many permanently.Matt Hancock’s new “track and trace” app may prove a great addition to the armoury against Covid- and we urge every Sun reader to download and use it when available. But we cannot wait for such tactics to bear fruit in the statistics.We are past the peak. Deaths are on their way down. The NHS was nowhere near being overwhelmed and that looks increasingly unlikely.The Government must not be swayed by the lockdown’s continued public support. That will evaporate once the long-term economic consequences sink in.We strongly disagree, though, with those who never thought it necessary — and make spurious comparisons of our death totals against countries of very dferent sizes and population densities.And we know what a tough call this is. But easing us imminently back to work and school, using social distancing and masks, is the right one. Yes, an NHS unable to cope would be a catastrophe.An even greater one is a prolonged lockdown . . . and a nation engulfed by bankruptcies, unemployment and poverty.WHAT a golden excuse the lockdown has been for every bossy busybody to exercise their authoritarian urges.Even so, we never imagined anyone would be mean-spirited enough to moan about the weekly clap for our ­carers — let alone for local councils to act on such petty grievances.One, however, has issued a warning to tone down the applause and Vera Lynn songs after a single complaint. Another has told a barman his sponsored singalong after the pm clap is too noisy.Do officials simply lack the backbone to tell these whingers to lump it Or do they actively enjoy sealing off ­avenues of pleasure EVEN in these grim times one announcement yesterday was too much to bear:“We have tried to make Love Island this summer, but it’s just not possible.”Our hearts are broken.What will we talk about now When will the Queen again address her disheartened nation Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lets get britain sewing
story: WE understand why scared Brits aren’t champing at the bit toto work.For nearly two months they’ve been told that staying at home saves lives and going out puts them in jeopardy.That’s all changing now: hospital admissions are down below , a day for the first time since March , and the NHS no longer looks in danger of being overwhelmed.But it’s only natural that workers remain cautious. If Boris Johnson is to get our flatlining economy going again, he and his Government must prove to the public that lockdown restrictions can be lted sensibly and safely.And that’s where homemade masks come in. Yes, we know they’re not perfect. But mounting evidence proves that insisting on their use in confined spaces can help slow the spread of the virus, and — crucially — they lend confidence.One way or another, it’s becoming crystal clear that after lockdown Britain will be very dferent from the country we remember. Gone are the days of a post-work pint in the pub to wind down:ministers permit us to socialise, it will be only for picnics, and only with those we consider our close friends.But with the economy on its knees, we must throw everything we’ve got at creating a “new normal” to tide us over until a vaccine can be found.Andmasks are part of that, then let’s get Britain sewing.OFFICIALS must stop hiding behind corona-jargon and start explaining in plain English exactly what they want from us.Guidance states thatyou’re classed as “extremely clinically vulnerable” you’re supposed to “shield”, andyou’re considered “clinically vulnerable” you should be “closely following social distancing rules”.The problem is thatyou’re over  and not in the habit of scrutinising government websites, you may understandably not know what the dference between those terms is. And so could be putting yourself through the misery of a  week self-isolation unnecessarily.Brits have given up most of their cherished liberties at the drop of a hat. Many of them have sacriced their jobs too.The very least they are owed is clear, comprehensive guidance on what the new normal is supposed to look like.THE news that McDonald’s will open  of its stores next week has cheered us up.Yes, it’s a blow that the lockdown menu is limited and some fan favourites didn’t make the cut. Butthe trial opening goes well, we have no doubt they will alsoAnd in the meantime, a world with McFlurries in it is definitely brighter.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: matt hancock doctor mp tone rosena
story: MATT Hancock has been slammed for calling out the shadow mental health minister and frontline AE doctor over her tone in the House of Commons yesterday.Dr Rosena Allin-Khan had demanded an answer on why testing numbers had fallen below the Health Secretarys own targets of , a day when he scolded her.Labour MP and AE worker Dr Allin-Khan said yesterday: Frontline workers like me have had to watch families break into pieces as we deliver the very worst of news that their loved ones have died.Thetesting strategy has been non-existent, community testing was scrapped, mass testing was slow to roll out, testing figures are now being manipulated.Will the Health Secretary commit to a minimum of , tests each day going forward, does the Secretary of State acknowledge that many frontline workers feel lack of testing has cost lives Instead of engaging with Dr Allin-Khans and healthcare workers concerns over testing, Mr Hancock scolded her for her tone telling her to take a leaf out of her colleague, the shadow Health Secretary Jonathan Ashworths, book.He said:would do well to take a leaf out of the Shadow Secretary of State’s book in terms of tone.I’m afraid what she said is not true. There’s been a rapid acceleration in testing over the last few months including getting to , tests a day.Dr Allin-Khan gave Mr Hancock a furious dressing down over his comments.She wrote on Twitter: I will respectfully challenge the Government - I want our country to succeed.However, I will not watch my tone when dozens of NHS and care staff are dying unnecessarily.Dr Allin-Khan has been taking up extra shts at a London hospital since the coronavirus crisis started, and has been vocal about the Governments failing on delivering enough personal protective equipment to NHS workers.She said: Undoubtedly it made for dficult listening and the hostile response reflects that, but it’s the truth, it’s fair to ask questions and frontline workers need their voices heard.Mr Ashworth hit out at Mr Hancock for dismissing the doctor MP.He said: My brilliant friend @DrRosena made her debut as a shadow health minister today speaking powerfully with great eloquence about the real experience of healthcare workers including herself on the frontline.She should be listened to and respected not dismissed out of hand.Other MPs piled in to defend Dr Allin-Khans performance.Labour MP for Putney title: cruel driver mows down ducklings
story: A man who saw the cruel kill in Holbeach, Lincolnshire, said a blue Ford C-Max failed to stop in Penny Hill Road last Friday, wiping out the mother duck and all but one of her feathered babies.The man, along with another couple, managed to get hold of the remaining duckling and rushed it to a nearby vet.Meanwhile, he has issued an appeal on social media to catch the driver.Alongside pictures of the devastating scene, the witness wrote: “Whoever intentionally hit these ducks and drove off in the blue Ford C-Max, I hope it was well worth it.“Sadly,didn’t get the number plate.“No other cars on the side of the road so could easily stopped and let them cross.“Luckily, a nice couple stopped and helped me catch the only duckling that survived and has taken it to the vet.”His post, published on a public Facebook page, has left thousands of people outraged.One person wrote: “Aww how cruel. How could anyone do something like this ”Another commented: “It’s horrible. Hopefully he or she gets all the karma they deserve.”One disgusted woman posted: “Absolutely disgusting – poor little things,” while another added: “there are some unkind people – it’s sad.”A petition has been set up by Carol Anderson to have road signs put up in the town, warning drivers of ducks in the road.In her petition, Carol says a number of ducks have lost their lives while crossing roads.The petition reads: “The town of Holbeach have a community of lovely ducks that are in constant danger of either being killed by reckless drivers, or causing an accident.“The latest example of this was a flock of about  ducks being wiped out by an HGV.“There is CCTV footage of a van running down a duck in Holbeach High Street. The driver didn’t even slow down.“More recently a whole family of ducklings were mown down by a careless driver, prompting an outcry on social media.“We feel that drivers need to be made aware of the possibility of ducks being in the road and would like Lincolnshire Highways to erect appropriate signage in key areas of the town where the ducks are most likely to be a hazard   in danger.” A spokesperson for the RSPCA told the Sun Online: This must have been very upsetting for the person who witnessed this.We would always advise motorists to keep a look out for wildle on the roads and to slow down in areas where they know wildle might be.It is unclear whether this was an accident orit was deliberate, so we would ask anyone with information to please contact the RSPCAs helpline on   .

title: britain could ease if over 70s stay home
story: BRITAIN could start to ease lockdown restrictionsover s stay shielded, scientists have said.Researchers from Edinburgh University have said keeping the most vulnerable people inside could allow more than half of Britain to have restrictions relaxed.The proposal from the researchers has been submitted to ministers as an option to allow millions of people toto work, according to .In one scenario looked at by the researchers in Edinburgh, the most vulnerable  per cent of society would only come into contact with a further  per cent of shielders including healthcare workers and family members.Ideally, the shielders would be tested for coronavirus every day to ensure they cant pass on the infection.The researchers said it would protect those most likely to have serious complications from coronavirus without risking a deadly second wave of infections that could overwhelm the NHS - the most critical test for easing lockdown.Ministers are worried it could amount to discriminationthe lockdown is eased for younger people, while older groups still have to heed stay-at-home advice.Professor of infectious disease epidemiology at Edinburgh University Mark Woolhouse said: The strategy works by concentrating efforts to control Covid- in the segment of the population that most needs protecting.It’s a nasty disease and we want to control it as much as we can, but it’s not so nasty in % of the population that we’d ever have contemplated locking down the whole country to control it.Professor Woolhouse stressed it would not be a magic bullet for curbing the outbreak, and contact tracing and other measures would still be crucial.Professor Woolhouse, who stressed he was speaking as an independent scientist, is also a member of the UK Government’s scientic pandemic influenza group on modelling .Former Conservative Party leader Iain Duncan Smith said: A lot of people over  are fit and have kept themselves fit, often more so than people of other ages.There has been a backlash and people don’t think it’s the right way to go about it.It was revealed yesterday that the Governments top scientists modelled a longer lockdown of around  weeks for older and vulnerable people, compared with eight to  weeks for everyone .The Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesfound the outcome of a longer lockdown for the most vulnerable could reduce deaths by up to  per cent - or up to  per centcombined with self-isolation for those who have symptoms and their households.Ministers are understood to have considered the idea, and Health Secretary Matt Hancock did not rule it out when pressed on the idea yesterday.A spokesman for No said earlier this week it was perfectly reasonably that we will look at how guidance will apply for dferent age bands and well continue to be guided by the science.There is a massively disproportionate risk of death when elderly and vulnerable people catch coronavirus.Boris Johnson is expected to lay out his blueprint for how Britain will ease restrictions on Sunday.Foreign Secretary Dominic Raab has said the next phase should be more comfortable and more sustainable for Brits.Restrictions on outdoor activities are likely to be lted first, Downing Street said yesterday.People may be able to enjoy the outdoors with small bubbles of families and friends over coming weeks.For the rest of Britain, some form of social distancing and hand hygiene will still be needed, but more drastic restrictions could be relaxed without setting off a second wave of infections.Oxford University professor of gerontology Sarah Harper said classing all over s as vulnerable would mean some healthy, active, older iniduals could be sentenced to their homes unfairly.She said: “Easing lockdown might be more effectivethe risks were explicitly explained to the population, the possible range of vulnerabilities highlighted and iniduals asked to take appropriate action.These are sensible public health approaches which might have a better chance of being complied with.Senior mental health experts share Professor Harpers concerns, saying healthy, elderly Brits needed to be freed from lockdown.  px,px, px" data-img"https:www.thesun title: exercise more lockdown
story: Ministers are looking at allowing more than one form of exercise a day during the first stage of Britain’s lockdown exit strategy.The Government are believed to favour more outdoor activity given the lower risk of infection compared to indoors.This could see the Prime Minister allow golf courses, tennis clubs and finish lakes to reopen next month.Mr Johnson is expected to renew the social distancing rules on Thursday before outlining his lockdown exit strategy on Sunday.Under the current lockdown rules people are only allowed outside their home to exercise once a day.According to the Mail Online, new guidelines will say golfers must use their own clubs and play just one other person.Tennis players could be asked to wear gloves on court, as well as restricted to playing with members of their household.Officials are also looking at whether open-air swimming could be includedchanging facilities stay shut.Outdoor exercise classes such as pilates and yoga could also participants are able to spread out in a large open space.It comes after the Governments Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencieswarned Ministers not to forget “low risk” changes that could boost the nations morale.They said: “It may be dficult to justy easing restrictions solely for economic activities without any easing of restrictions for low risk activities with signicant social and psychological benefit.”Ministers are also looking at letting people meet up with a small “bubble” of their friends and relatives.Families could also be allowed to leave their home more often, and for longer, in time to soak up the summer sunshine.The proposals are being considered by ministers as they try to carve a path out of the strict lockdown and to a “new normal”. px,px, px" title: meghan markle baby archie first birthday
story: The mum is seen reading Duck! Rabbit! to the birthday boy as proud dad Harry films them - quacking in the background.The book is one of Archies favourite stories - with the one-year-old giggling and helping to turn the pages in the adorable clip.And Meghan - who wore a casual denim shirt and shorts in a departure from the more royal wardrobe - beamed as she played with her little boy to celebrate his first birthday.In the video, the mum, , encourages Archie to read along - revealing her nickname for her son as she cooed lets go to the next page, look Arch.At one point, the little boy appears to get upset but is quickly cheered up by his mum as she reads the storybook.And in the cute home movie, Archie is then distracted as he grabs a second book with Meghan laughing Lets finish this book first.Harry is heard chuckling at his sons antics from behind the camera.As Meghan finishes up the book, she cuddles and kisses her sons head as Harry, , cheers and cries the end! and bravo.Happy Archie then looks at his dad grinning as he chews on the corner of the book - babbling dada.The young royal - who is the spitting image of his dad - sports a full head of hair and several new teeth in the video, which is thought to have been recorded in Calornia where Meghan and Harry are now living.The video was shared on Instagram by Save the Children to help raise urgent funds for the charitys coronavirus appeal that has seen other celebs including Jenner Garner and Amy Adams read stories.They said: Duck! Rabbit! with Meghan, The Duchess of Sussex , read to their son Archie for his st birthday.Happy Birthday, Archie!Thank you Duchess Meghan for helping us to raise urgent funds for our coronavirus appeal by reading Duck! Rabbit by @akrfoundation, illustrated by @tlichtenheld .The popular book, by Amy Krouse Rosenthal and illustrated by Tom Lichtenheld, playfully asks whether an ambiguous image is a duck or a rabbit.The little boy - who is seventh in line to the throne - is expected to mark his first birthday with Zoom calls to his aunt Kate and uncle William.And in a message posted on Twitter this morning, the Cambridges wished Archie a very happy first birthday today.The sweet note was shared online along with a photograph of the family posing at his christening.Proud grandparents Prince Charles and Camilla also joined the birthday wishes, sharing a photo of Prince Harry cradling Archie at his christening as his dad looks on.They wrote: A very Happy Birthday to Archie, who turns one today.This photo of Archie and his grandfather was taken following his christening in July .And the Royal Family Twitter account also shared a message to the littlest royal.They wrote: Happy Birthday to Archie Mountbatten-Windsor who is celebrating his st birthday today!Archie is The Queen’s eighth great-grandchild.And Archie and his parents Meghan and Harry are also expected to call the Queen for the one-year-olds birthday.It will be a relatively quiet day for the family in Calornia, having moved to LA just before America went into lockdown to stop the spread of coronavirus.The couple have made Los Angeles their home and they and other residents of Calornia have been living under a stay-at-home order made by the states governor Gavin Newsom.And royal write Katie Nicholl said Archie was likely to chat with his cousins George, Charlotte and Louis online.Speaking to "OK! Magazine she said: “The Queen will wish him happy birthday this week via Zoom as will the Cambridge children.“They haven’t seen their little cousin in months so they’ve been looking forward to seeing how much he’s grown.”America is where Meghan and Harry plan to bring up their son after walking away from the royal family in order to become financially independent, after their hopes of earning money while still supporting the Queen were ruled out.The young royal has experienced an eventful  months since he was born at Londons Portland Hospital - first living in a cottage in the grounds of Windsor Castle, then an exclusive home on Vancouver Island in Canada and now in the sprawling metropolis known as the City of Angels.Archie was born on May   at .am, weighing lb oz, and a few days after his birth his parents proudly showed him to the world, before the Queen and Duke of Edinburgh saw the infant for the first time.Meghans mother Doria Ragland, a yoga instructor and social worker, was pictured at the royal gathering and she has been a constant presence in the Sussexes lives, and lives in Los Angeles where Meghan grew up and went to school.He received his greatest exposure when the Sussexes took their son on his first royal tour, visiting South Africa last autumn when he was four months old.The royal baby received a welcome kiss from Archbishop Desmond Tutu when Harry and Meghan introduced him to one of the heroes of the anti-Apartheid movement.Archie made an impression with the Archbishops daughter Thandeka Tutu-Gxashe, who joked the young royal favoured ladies better when she caught him glancing in her direction and Meghan declared he likes to flirt.Earlier in  Archie was photographed in his mothers arms while his father took part in a charity polo match.Meghan and Harry are the subject of a highly anticipated book, due for publication in August, which its authors have said they want to be a definitive story about the couple.And in another development in their lives, the duchess lost the first High Court skirmish in her claim against the publisher of the Mail on Sunday over publication of a private and confidential letter to her estranged father.Meghan is suing Associated Newspapers over five articles, two in the Mail on Sunday and three on MailOnline, which were published in February  and reproduced parts of a handwritten letter she sent to Thomas Markle, , in August .In a ruling last Friday, Mr Justice Warby struck out parts of Meghans claim against the publisher, including allegations that it acted dishonestly by leaving out certain passages of the letter, following an application by Associated Newspapers.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus elon musk scientist lockdown rules social distancing
story: Musk tweeted on Tuesday that Neil Ferguson, a -year-old professor and top scientist in the UK government, was a “tool” after he allowed Antonia Staats, , to visit him at his home.Ferguson had led the team at Imperial College London that handed a bombshell piece of research to the government that prompted the nationwide lockdown.The team’s findings indicated that failing to take drastic action amid the outbreak could cause , deaths and National Health Serviceto be overwhelmed.Last week, Ferguson warned lting the lockdown too early could risk an additional , deaths.But despite this, he still allowed his married girlfriend who has children into his home at least twice — and Ferguson ended up resigning because of the scandal.Musk, the billionaire founder of SpaceX who recently had a child of his own, tweeted that “something more should be done” about Ferguson.“This guy has caused massive stre to the world with his absurdly fake ‘science,’” Musk wrote online.His tweets came in response to a post that read: Hey @neil_ferguson: F**k you. You shut down the world but ignored the lockdown to fuck a married woman  How’s that for tone Ferguson accepted he had made an error of judgment and took the wrong course of action.”I have therefore stepped back from my involvement in Sage [the governments Scientic Advisory Group for Emergencies], he told The .I acted in the belief that I was immune, having tested positive for coronavirus, and completely isolated myself for almost two weeks after developing symptoms.”I deeply regret any undermining of the clear messages around the continued need for social distancing to control this devastating epidemic.”Ferguson continued: The government guidance is unequivocal, and is there to protect all of us.Musk has publicly come out against social distancing guidelines, and last week tweeted: “FREE AMERICA NOW.”The -year-old shared an op-ed which questioned whether stay-at-home orders at saving lives, and added: Give people their freedom back!Musk then congratulated Texas for reopening businesses, and added in another tweeted that although reopening should be done with care  appropriate protection the public should not be put under de facto house arrest.”One follower commented: The scariest thing about this pandemic is not the virus itself, it’s seeing American so easily bow down  give up their blood bought freedom to corrupt politicians who promise them safety.Musk responded: True.In the US, more than , people have died from the coronavirus and President Donald Trump recently said it’s “possible” more Americans will die as states reopen businesses.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: apocalyptic scenes sand storm arican city
story: The giant sand storm hit the city of Niamey, Niger on Monday.Sandstorms arent unusual during the West African dry season, which is from January to April.The season is known as the Harmattan.But its the dryer areas around North Africa and the Arabian peninsula which are hit with the most dust - prompting some to suggest Nigers storm was unusual.But scenes in Niamey were jaw-dropping, as a huge wall of dust engulfed the city.One viral video appears to show a tsunami of dust poised behind Naimers skyline.Huge orange clouds of dust could be seen eerily floating above the city before crashing into a giant red wave that bled through the sky.In another video the entire sky is crimson, the camera panning through a window which shows a square of blood-red against the white background of the wall.At one point, a staircase becomes completely engulfed by the cloud of dust - appearing ominously skeletal against the blood red.One man says: Dude, this is kinda cool, kinda weird, kinda scary. Wow, amazing.Social media users described the incredible scenes as apocalyptic.One wrote: My apocalypse bingo card is full now.Another added: I witnessed it, and that was damn scary.Some even questioned ine intervention, with one person writing: This is actually rather unusual. Some people are saying that its God punishment.The storms occur when thunderstorms elevate huge quantities of dust into the air.The plumes can travel for hundreds of kilometres before releasing ungodly amounts of dust onto unsuspecting cities.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: modern romeo juliet verona balconies meet coronavirus lockdown
story: A “MODERN-day Romeo and Juliet” who fell in love from their Verona balconies have finally met after Italy’s coronavirus lockdown was lted.Michele D’Alpaos, , an IT expert, and Paola Agnelli, , a lawyer, caught each other’s eye during one of the country’s famous “balcony concerts” in March, it’s reported.They started talking on social media and now, nearly two months later, the couple have finally met in person and exchanged their first kiss.Paola told the Times: “We were both nervous but it went really well.“He was just like I imagined he would be.”Their heartwarming love story has been compared to Shakespeare’s Romeo and Juliet – set in the same city – in which Romeo calls up to his lover as she stands on her balcony in an iconic scene.Their tale all began with Paola’s sister playing the violin as locked down neighbours gathered on their balconies to listen – a popular trend that has emerged across Europe during isolation.Paola was helping with the sound as Michele listened when the pair spotted each other.She said the music the music was “like an arrow fired by Eros” – the Greek god of love.She told Femail: “The first time I saw him it was love at first sight and for him as well – our eyes just met each other.“The atmosphere was so romantic.”Michele found out who Paola was through his sister Sylvia, who goes to the same gym, according to one report.He reached out to her on Instagram, and their relationship blossomed from there.The pair started messaging until am like “teenagers in love”, the Mail reports.And now the couple have finally met up in person for the first time in a local park after Italy eased its lockdown restrictions.Michele told the Times: “It was wonderful to finally meet her, she is more beautul than I thought.”And Paola told This Morning: “Im very happy as now I can see him, hold him, kiss him, and… I can see him in every spare moment.”The Italian government introduced a vague set of rules allowing those with a “stable bond of affection” to meet beginning Monday.Paola told the Times: “We discussed it because we didn’t want to end up being punished, rather like Shakespeare’s characters. “But we decided we fit the bill, and got closer than a meter at our meeting.”Michele currently lives with his parents, but bought his own apartment which he has yet to move into, he said.He told the Times: “I have been showing Paola photos of it and we are making plans to move in.”Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on title: hug grandkids matt hancock
story: During a QA with Sky News, the Health Secretary said that they may be able to ease some shielding and social distancing measuresthe number of new confirmed virus cases is slashed.Today more than , new confirmed positive cases of the bug were reported, the latest figures show.Millions of families have been torn apart for nearly six weeks, since the UK went into nationwide lockdown on March .No one is allowed out except for four reasons - and Brits should not be visiting family they do not live with.Linda, who is isolating as she is in a very vulnerable group of people who has been told to stay inside, asked Mr Hancock this morning:  Am I going to have to wait until a vaccine  is found before I can hug my grandchildren and see friends or are other options being considered to guarantee my safety outside lockdown Mr Hancock said that those very vulnerable people have been asked to stay inside and have as little contact as possible for at least  weeks.Only people who have got a letter from their GP telling them to do this should be completely isolating, he stressed.We may have to extend that, but we hope not to have to, he added.We may well be able to release some of those measures before a vaccine is available,we can get the number of new cases right down.In some countries we have managed to get the number of new cases right down.If we get there and succeed, then we will be able to take clinical advice on whether its safe for those people be able to hug their grandchildren.The Health Secretary said he understood the plight of those who havent been able to leave their homes for at least six weeks.They were at the front of my mind but he wanted to make sure they were kept safe at all costs.Everyone should follow social distancing guidelines, he added.Those who are shielded are shielded for their own protection.But the Health Secretary revealed he played Frisbee at the weekend with his three kids – and insists it does not flout the rules.Mr Hancock, , told Sky News: “This weekend I managed to play Frisbee in the park with my kids and so take some exercise.”Askedthis was allowed in the era of social distancing he said: “Yes it is because it is exercise in the park.“Exercise is one of the important reasons that people can go out.”Lambeth Council in London has stuck up signs around their parks telling visitors there is a strict “no ball games” policy.While enforcement officers in Tower Hamlets in east London have told locals they cannot play basketball eventhey are alone.There was no guarantee that a vaccine could be found - but companies were making huge strides towards one, he stressed.Britain is at the forefront of a global race with at least two trials starting in humans.Scientists hope to known in just a couple of title: spanish flu photographs coronavirus pandemic
story: Even though the Spanish flu outbreak happened in  it seems the response has remarkable similarities to the current pandemic affecting hundreds of thousands of people across the world.Face masks became a vital piece of equipment during the  Spanish Flu – for those out for a walk on a street, Red Cross nurses treating the injured or a worker spraying the top of a London bus.While many masks were made of cotton, some innovated and hooked themselves up to breathing contraptions, believing the air itself was toxic.While the origins of the original influenza outbreak  have never been fully determined it became known as Spanish flu although is also known as the  flu pandemic which was caused by the HN influenza A virus.It first appeared in spring  and lasted until early summer .Estimates say around million people were affected, about a third of the world’s population, at the time.It’s thought the death toll to have been between m and m people, making it one of the deadliest pandemics ever.In an effort to keep morale strong during World War I, censors minimised early reports of the illness and mortality rates but because Spain had remained neutral newspapers were free to report the epidemic’s effects in the country, including the illness of King Alfonso XIII.Those reports helped fuel the impression Spain was especially badly affected by the disease, giving rise to the name Spanish flu.The outbreak seemed affect young adults, who had a particularly high death rate from the disease.Scientists have given a number of explanations why this was with some analyses indicating that it triggered a “cytokine storm” which attacked the stronger immune system of young adults.However a  study of medical journals at the time found the viral infection was no more aggressive than previous influenza strains.It found that malnourishment, overcrowded medical camps and hospital as well as poor hygiene, all made worse by the recent war, promoted a bacterial superinfection.

title: another lockdown longer square one
story: Sir David King today claimed the nation would undo all its good workhit with a second wave of the coronavirus.The Governments former Chief Scientic Adviser was in the role between  and , and now urged the nation to stick with it to see off the pandemic.Appearing on BBC News, he said: “A second spike is going to take us back to square one.“It means we go into lockdown again and we go into lockdown for longer.“That would be bad for our economy and also bad for the number of fatalities.”Sir David also bashed the Government’s approach, saying “we have fared extremely badly”.The -year-old has set up his own  of experts to rival the Governments in a bid to hammer out how the UK can exit lockdown.He made the  after slamming the Scientic Advisory Group for Emergenciesfor failing to be transparent or disclose their modelling or members.Sir David accused political advisors including PMs top advisor Dominic Cummings of intervening in scientic decisions and influencing advice.He said: Why we didn’t respond so much sooner once this epidemic broke out in China, I simply don’t know.And I say this because in , we published a report on actions needed to deal with a pandemic and in that report, we showed thatan outbreak occurred of any new virus of this kind, anywhere in the world, within three months, due to air travel, it would be everywhere in the world and that, of course, is what has happened.He said Britain was unprepared for the outbreak and we didnt take action.Dominic Raab warned of a second spike yesterday, warning its why schools cant all go back at once.He said: The evidence has been that we wouldnt be able to open up all schools, without a very real risk that the R rate or the transmission rate would rise at such a level that we would risk a second spike.The crucial bit for us is the five tests, and the risk of having a second spike in relation to any new changes that we would make, but that must of course include schools.Boris Johnson has set five tests that need to be met before it will start easing the lockdown that has been in place since March .The final test is that the government and medical professionals must be certain that there will not be a risk of a second wave of infection, similar to that in Germany.The Prime Minister is expected to deliver an address to the nation on Sunday, May , in which he intends to unveil a road map out of title: student loan debt could scrapped
story: Rep. Carolyn Maloney introduced the bill on Tuesday for the hero workers, many of who still owe hundreds of thousands of dollars.It comes as New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo suggested a  per cent hazard pay.Gov. Cuomo said last month: Essential public workers are the ones on the front lines every day carrying us through this crisis.We must ensure their efforts and sacrice are appropriately recognized.However, several healthcare workers came forward to speak out against the idea - with suggestions the rise in pay would barely make a dent in medical school debt.Some medics leave their studies with , in debt, says the Association of American Medical Colleges.One medic who spoke out against the hazard pay was -year-old Dr. Manuel Penton III.He said: That few extra thousand dollars, while it may make a big dference to some people, for me, most of that money is going to go back into paying off my student loan debt.And last month, more than , people signed a petition asking Congress to introduce forgiving student loan debt for doctors in the next stimulus bill.Meanwhile, dozens of health care organizations, including the American Medical Association wrote a letter to Congress asking for student loan of at least , for residents and early graduated medical students whose debt averages over , to be scrapped.Many final year medics graduated early to join the frontline fight against coronavirus.Typically, doctors will pay off their debts after working for ten years - although time spent in residency is considered.Other factors for students are switching to a payment plan that considers your income, taking out more hefty loans - or living below your means.There are also loan forgiveness programs for medics willing to work in the public sector or serve underprivileged areas.Do you have a story for The US Sun team Email us at exclusive@the-sun or call   .Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: indonesia earthquake magnitude tremor screaming beds
story: The quake reportedly struck in the Banda Sea,  miles from the nearest city, Saumlaki.It struck at a depth of  miles, according to the US Geological Survey.The quake was confirmed to have a magnitude of ., a strength which can cause signicant damage, particularlyit strikes it a populated area.Many residents were reportedly shaken in their beds and forced to get up and leave their homes.People were asleep, we screamed, said one.People ran because of the quake, beds shook.The Indonesia Tsunami Service Provider added that it was not powerful enough to trigger any tsunami in the region.Some injuries have been reported, but the US Geological Survey has said that economic losses are unlikely.Indonesia sits on the so-called Ring of Fire, a ,-mile chain of  volcanoes around the edge of the tectonic place that lies beneath the Pacic Ocean.The ring runs up past Asia and Russia, across to Alaska, and down the westerly coasts of North and South America.Since , about  per cent of the most powerful eruptions in the world have happened along this boundary.Indonesia already saw one of the most devastating earthquakes on record in , when a .-magnitude quake struck undersea off the island of Sumatra.The quake caused a tsunami that killed , people in Indonesia and , others on other shorelines around the Indian Ocean.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: six bed country manor where james bond star sir roger moore stayed is on sale for 3 95m
story: And there’s plenty of licence to thrill in the Grade II listed country house, Fredley Manor, near Dorking, thanks to its  acres of grounds, swimming pool and woodland.Listed with House Partnership for a cool £.m, Fredley Manor was originally a cottage on the Fredley Manor estate.However, it was sold many times between  and , including by London hatter and trader Richard Sharp.Between  and  he entertained politicians and poets such as Sir Walter Scott, William Wordsworth and Samuel Coleridge.The listing describes the property as an extremely attractive Grade II listed country house situated in the wonderful rural surroundings of the North Surrey Hills within walking distance of the village and pub.It enjoys far reaching views over the lower slopes of Boxhill and it is surrounded by acres of National Trust Land.”Fredley Manor, in the North Surrey Hills, is set in an expansive  acres of grounds and boasts six stunning bedrooms with period wooden beam features, all of which have access to an en-suite or adjoining additional bathroom.The property has a huge country-style farmhouse kitchen with Aga, large island and Belfast sink, drawing room and stunning led dining room.There’s plenty to keep the family occupied at the sprawling , sq. ft. manor as it comes with a study, swimming pool, paddock and woodland.And of course it offers plenty of interesting history - theres a veritable whos who when it comes to previous ownership.At one stage the manor was owned by British film producer and director, James Clavell.So, between  and , Clavell welcomed the likes of  James Bond, Sir Roger Moore, and Dallas’ Larry Hagman who played JR Ewing in the hit show.Despite its secluded location, the property has excellent links to London via the A, and is just a short distance from Sandown, Epsom, Kempton, Ascot and Goodwood.Dorking is just two miles away with Heathrow and Gatwick Airports an approximately -mile drive.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: coronavirus tracing app phone batteries apple
story: TECH giant Apple are warning new NHS contact tracing app may drain smartphone batteries, The Sun can reveal.NHS developers have used Apple bluetooth technology  in a new way on the NHSx contact tracing app so it can work effectively - but insiders warn the new system risks having “teething problems” including draining batteries.The app is currently being tested in a pilot scheme on the Isle of Wight.NHSX staff have used Apples internal bluetooth API software in a way never done before so that the contact tracing app can run on an iPhone in the background, dashing fears that it would not work like similar apps in Singapore and Australia.Although there were fears the same would happen to the NHSx app, NHSX developers have worked around the software so there isn’t a similar block.Similar apps created by third party developers for governments have become redundant as it emerged that the iPhone stops them sending the data when the phone is locked.The new method hasn’t yet been tested and may drain batteries.A source at the tech firm said: “This is the first time that API has been used in this way and using like this is unproven and may cause battery issues.”They added: ”The NHS team used Apple’s Core Bluetooth API to enable the app to run bluetooth in the background.“Using the Google Apple API means ‘issues’ are less likely to arise.”But sources at the Department of Health said they don’t expect the battery drain to be an issue and added: “Our developers have said this hasn’t been an issue but this is why we are rolling out a test phase in the Isle of Wight to iron out any issues.“In  percent of cases there isn’t an issue, and when there are it is only in extreme examples.“These aren’t big issues, it is things in the woodwork that come up and we are sorting out.“It is certainly not the case thattwo are running the app in the background that they are not going to ping.“If that were the case the app would not be sustainable.”They denied that the app would drain battery le, with developers “pretty adamant” that it will have no effect.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.There have been no issues with the app Google’s Android system.The Sun understands a meeting between the tech firms and the NHSX team will happen later this week to discuss any further issues ahead of a national roll out.Apple declined to comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: japan draws up ufo encounter plan
story: Three videos were released by the US defence department after they leaked showing military pilots encounters with UFOs.Japans defence ministry is now said to be preparing a plan of action for their pilots to deal with any such unexplained events, reports Nippon.Defence chiefs are plotting out how pilots can respond to, record and report any unusual encounters with unidentied objects.Taro Kono, defence minister, said Japans pilots have never reported any UFOs, but the protocols are being prepared to cover the possibility.F- pilots are reportedly set to be briefed on the potential encounters which officials fear may confuse them.Fighter jets at seven bases across Japan are scrambled to monitor and identy any unknown aircraft - and now they will have a proper reporting procedure for UFOs.It came as the Pentagon finally released three clips showing their pilots interacting with unexplained phenomena after determining the footage did not reveal any sensitive capabilities or systems.The US defence department said after review the three clips dont impinge on any subsequent investigations of [these types of] military air space incursions.The clips show three separate incidents involving unidentied aerial phenomena, one from November  and two from January .The  video shows the infamous USS Nimitz Tic Tac incident, shot by pilot Chad Underwood.And the two incidents from  show similar hovering objects as pilots exclaim what the f*** is that thing !.The Tic Tac incident unfolded during aircraft carrier group exercises in the Pacic, off the coast of Mexico, with six pilots in total spotting the strange sight.They described seeing a Tic Tac-shaped object about  feet long hovering some  feet above the water.One baffled pilot who spotted the UFO said: It would go from like  feet off the ground... it looked like it was just hovering over the water.“But there was no method of propulsion that was keeping it airborne: no wings, no heat, keeping it airborne or aloft.”One pilot reportedly said the object accelerated off like nothing I’ve ever seen when the aircraft approached.After part of the clip leaked in , the Pentagon acknowledged the existence of its Advanced Aerospace Threat Identication Program - which was founded in  to study UFOs before being disbanded in .Former senator, Harry Reid said he was glad the Pentagon had released the material, but hinted the clips only scratched the surface.He added: The US needs to take a serious, scientic look at this and any potential national security implications. The American people deserve to be informed.US President Donald Trump called the footage a hell of a video - before musing I just wonderits real.In a statement upon the release of the clips, the Pentagon said: The US Navy previously acknowledged that these videos circulating in the public domain were indeed Navy videos.DOD is releasing the videos in order to clear up any misconceptions by the public on whether or not the footage that has been circulating was real, or whether or not there is more to the videos.The aerial phenomena observed in the videos remain characterized as unidentied.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pockets uk coronavirus infections spike face tight restrictions
story: THE government has said it will make interventions in micro communitiesthey see local infection spikes.Under the Prime Ministers blueprint to end lockdown, the whole nation will see the tough restrictions gradually eased at the same time, with the end of May targeted.However the government today admitted they could be quickly re-imposed on certain areas that see a rise in coronavirus cases.Speaking at the daily Downing Street press conference, Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said: Our strong preference is that our whole country moves as one.Butits required for us to make interventions in smaller, sort of micro-communities, where youre seeing the virus take hold again, then that will be something that we consider as other countries around the world have done where theyve implemented effective track and trace systems.But thats quite dferent from making major changes to lockdown measures in one part of the country to another and our strong preference is for the whole country to move as one.The plan to hit hard any Covid- hotspots that erupt when the lockdown is lted has been dubbed a whack-a-mole strategy within Whitehall.The move to single out specic towns has infuriated the nations nine regional mayors.Fears deepened of longer lockdowns for some towns as it emerged the crisis in London - where the outbreak started - could be over sooner than in other parts of the UK.There are now less people being treated in hospital with Covid- in the capital than in the North West.We reported how the mayors mounted a joint protest to Mr Johnson during a conference call with him last week.They argued that leaving some pockets of the country unable to keep up with others in the national recovery would be unsustainable as well as deeply isive and unfair.It comes as the PM said social distancing restrictions will start to be lted from Monday.The three-week review of lockdown restrictions must take place tomorrow but Mr Johnson wont set out changes until Sunday.More than one form of daily exercise is expected to be among the first signs of easing.Earlier, Matt Hancock, the health secretary, indicated outdoor cafés could soon open.He told Sky News: There is strong evidence that outdoors the spread is much, much lower, so there may be workarounds that some businesses, for instance cafés, may be able to put into place.Mr Johnson has promised plans for socially distanced work, travel and schooling as part of the roadmap out of the nations virtual house arrest.A total of , people in the UK have now died in hospitals, care homes and the wider community, up by  from Tuesday.On Tuesday, the number of deaths recorded in the UK passed Italys total, becoming the highest in Europe.To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day -
