title: gyms closed lockdown autumn coronavirus
story: GYMS have been told they must stay shut until autumn at the earliest after Government officials deemed them one of the worst places for spreading coronavirus.Government scientists are understood to have grouped them with bars and restaurants, which will be among the last venues to reopen. More pessimistic forecasts within government have even predicted that gyms won’t reopen this year.An industry source in talks with the Government said: “Six months is a reasonable timeframe.”Whitehall officials who have been working with industry bodies on plans to reopen workplaces have concluded that like bars and restaurants, gyms are a “hotbed of infection”.A source who has been involved in extensive talks with government officials over the ‘Back to Work’ plans said: “Gyms won’t be open any time soon.“It won’t be sooner than autumn.”Another of those involved in the planning said: “One way systems don’t work in gyms as people don’t use the equipment in order like aisles in Tesco.“They are in close proximity in the wet environment of changing rooms, while exercise means lots of sweat and huffing and puffing in close quarters.”But some gyms have urged the Government to allow them to open for personal trainers and their clients.They have argued this could work because gyms could operate in a much more controlled environment where personal trainers could keep two metres away from their clients but also clean equipment after every use.The Treasury is understood to be working on plans to extend its wage support scheme for the specic sectors that are told to stay shut.That could see gym employees kept on some form of the taxpayer-funded job retention scheme, which currently pays  per cent of wages for workers who have been furloughed by their employer.The current scheme is currently due to end in June but Chancellor Rishi Sunak has assured employers that they will not face a “clf-edge”.Huw Edwards, CEO of ukactive, said: “The timeline for reopening gyms and leisure centres has not yet been confirmed and ukactive continues to work with the Government on this important issue.“Our sector is taking every step necessary to ensure it is able to reopen safely and as soon as the Government allows, in order to provide vital services for the health of our nation.“It is important the Government understands the unique role these facilities play in our society, with public leisure alone contributing £.bn towards our population’s health and wellbeing, and gyms and leisure centres employing around , people.”A Government spokesperson said: “The Business Secretary continues to work with businesses, union leaders and the science and medical community so we can ensure workplaces are safe for those who will go back to work once the measures are relaxed and give people the confidence toto work.”Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your title: brits wrongly told extremely vulnerable coronavirus
story: MORE than , Brits have wrongly been told they are “extremely vulnerable” to Covid- and ordered to stay indoors for  weeks.The NHS starting writing to high-risk people six weeks ago urging them to remain at home at all times.As a result, some couples were forced to sleep in separate bedrooms and parents to keep away from their children.Brits in the “shielded” group include those with suppressed immune systems, such as cancer and transplant patients.It means they are eligible for help, such as food parcels and prescription deliveries, from the NHS volunteer army. But the hastily-drawn list – which has since bulged to . million - saw , dead people being sent letters.Now it has emerged that , were wrongly told they were high risk, according to the Health Service Journal.It means they do not have to remain indoors until late June, although they still have to observe other social distancing measures.But GPs have only now started sending out letters saying they can carry out essential activities outdoors - more than a month after they were locked down.Matt Hancock is considering extending the -week shielding period for the most vulnerable Brits.The Health Secretary told Sky News: “Weve asked those being shielded to avoid as much contact as possible for  weeks.We may have to extend that  weeks but we hope not to.” Mr Hancock said he hoped to release some measures before a vaccine is foundcases continue to fall.He added: If we succeed in doing that we will be able to take clinical advice on whether it is safe for those who are shielded to, for instance, hug their grandchildren. That is right at the front of my mind.A Department of Health spokesperson said: “People are added and removed from the shielding list regularly based on their GPs clinical judgement, with . million patients identied as being clinically extremely vulnerable so far.“GPs are be best placed to advise on the needs of their inidual patients during this time andanybody is concerned they should be included on the list, they should discuss with their GP.”To receive The Suns Coronavirus newsletterevery tea time, sign up here.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brits unlimited outdoor exercise monday
story: BRITS are to be set free to enjoy unlimited exercise from Monday. Cafes could re-open outdoor spaces soon after, in an easing of lockdown restrictions. Park picnics may also be on again, as long as people stay two metres apart.The relaxation of the coronavirus lockdown is the first of many that the PM plans to roll out week by week to reward long-suffering Brits.Mr Johnson will unveil his long-awaited “unlockdown” plan on Sunday to gradually end the nation’s virtual house arrest.Aides say he will make clear the vast bulk of restrictions will remain for some weeks.But he will announce everyone can take “unlimited exercise” from Monday. Currently people are only allowed to go out for one form a day.Friends and family will be allowed to have park picnics and sit on benches -they keep two metres apart. The move will let them get together on the grass without fear of being harassed, stared at or moved on.The measures could also come into effect next week, possibly as early as Monday.The Government is also looking at allowing people to play non-contact sports such as golf and tennis.A senior source told The Sun: “The PM wants people to know that all the effort they’ve put in is delivering progress, that six weeks of doing nothing has been worthwhile.“So we can now let off the brake a bit, and see what happens. If people abide by the new rules, we can then let off the brake a little bit more.”Mr Johnson will also try to persuade bosses to allow work to resume in sectors that were not told they must close.They include construction sites as well as some retail outlets, including dry cleaners and ­takeaways such as McDonald’s.Mr Johnson wants to put timelines on when Brits can expect measures to take effect “where he can”, sources said.One key date he is pushing to announce is for a staggeredto schools, with the ­current target being June .But the PM will insist there is no spike in the R rate — the measure of how many people an infected person passes the bug on to.It also emerged yesterday he is preparing to unveil a new slogan for Phase Two of the battle.Officials ordered all their teams to remove the current one — “Stay at Home, Protect the NHS, Save Lives” — from websites and social media on Saturday night.Revealing his plan to announce the initial easing of lockdown, the PM told MPs yesterday: “We have to be sure the data is going to support our ability to do this. That data is coming in continuously over the next few days. We wantwe possibly can to get going with some of these measures on Monday.”Earlier, Health Secretary Matt Hancock suggested that as lockdown measures are eased the public couldto pavement cafes.There is strong evidence that outdoors the spread is much, much lower, so there may be workarounds that some businesses, for instance cafes, especially over the summer, may be able to put into place, he told Sky News.Meanwhile, van drivers may have to sit up front on their own under tough new guidance on work vehicles. A crackdown on passengers will also affect truckers and delivery drivers.Employers will be sent diagrams showing how many workers should be in vehicles to help shield against the virus.Drafts of the guidance — shared with industry leaders ­earlier this week — say only the driver should sit up front.It advises a maximum of two people in each vehicle, though that can be morethey are from the same household.The advice says vans without back seats should have just a driver up front, with other workers encouraged to travel separately. Vehicles with three seats in the front can have a passenger on the far side only.The new guidelines will affect a host of workers including taxi drivers, who will not be able to fill a five-seater under the plans.Work vehicles would also have to be frequently cleaned, with hand sanitisers for workers getting in and out.The guidance, due to be sent out next week, will also encourage staff at distribution centres and depots to avoid close ­interaction with the driver.First Secretary Dominic Raab will today confirm that the ­Government is extending the lockdown again as he announces the results of its second review.By law, ministers must review it every three weeks.But Mr Raab will ask the nation to wait for the PM’s announcement on Sunday to find out more.Housing Secretary Robert Jenrick last night called for work on construction and big transport projects to restartsafety measures are in place.After complaints from regional mayors, Mr Jenrick said it is the Government’s “strong preference” that lockdown measures are lted at the same time across the country.But he told the No daily press briefing that local restrictions could be reimposedthere was a new outbreak.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: young people work economy moving
story: COVID- has delivered a stinging haymaker to the UK economy.The question now is how quickly it will get off the floor.And the truth is, as with so much right now, nobody quite knows.But two things are certain: A recession is coming, and the longer lockdown lasts, the longer Britain will spend on the canvas.So getting Britain’s economy going again must be a priority.And as we find out more and more about who is at risk from this plague, it is becoming increasingly clear that getting people like me — the young — back to work is the first and most sensible step on the road to recovery.We all know that coronavirus hits the oldest hardest.Nobody proposing lting lockdown measures is ignoring the horrendous inidual tragedies of all of those who pass.Every time the number of deaths goes up by just one, that is another family who have lost a dear loved one.But that does not change the fact that out of the more than , Brits who have sadly succumbed to Covid-, fewer than  have been under .I have lost count of the number of conversations I have had with fed-up friends who, like me, are desperate to get back to work, to continue with their hard-fought-for careers.If anyone might be safe toto work — and, of course, no one is completely safe from this bastard of a virus — then it is us.Just about every measure of the economy, from car sales to manufacturing performance, has hit a record low over the last few weeks — and that will only get worse.Some economic forecasters reckon it could take more than three years to get the economy back to where it was at the start of .And top economic wonks at the Institute For Fiscal Studies reckon youngsters will be hit hardest by the coming recession. I am , so when I joined the workforce we were in the midst of a financial crisis that plunged the economy into paralysis.I have endured years of political to-ing and fro-ing over spending, infrastructure projects and — whether you voted for it or not — Westminster’s tortuous Brexit chicanery that has slowed down economic growth.The price  Real wages, measured alongside inflation, only got back above their  levels this year.House prices shot up to unaffordable levels, with governments promising to build the houses we need but failing miserably to take on the vested interests that stand in the way.Young people could already only dream of owning a home before the world shut down.Just this week, a friend sent round a story on WhatsApp about the possibility of house prices collapsing.We all just laughed and agreed we still could not get anywhere near a deposit, and not because we have been enjoying too much avocado toast.And just as we looked forward to a British bounce once Brexit was in the rear-view mirror, now a global pandemic has made  look like nothing more than a trailer for the main event in which this young generation, yet again, gets a starring role.It is not just about getting money moving and business booming, either.The temporary schemes introduced by the Government to get people through the worst of this crisis will leave a borrowing pile that not even Jeremy Corbyn and John McDonnell could have dreamed up.Most likely, that means higher taxes and lower spending for decades. In short, Britain’s under-s are being condemned to years of an economy going backwards.So it is time for them to be allowed back to work and start the recovery. We should all be invested in British companies’ success.The better they do, the more jobs they create, the more they can pay, the better le is. Yes, there is a risk to getting the young back to work.But witness the orderly queues outside supermarkets and the pavement shuffle dance that we have all perfected to give each other space.The public, young and old, understand the threat of this virus.We invented all these video apps everyone is now socialising on. We are more than happy to use them for a little while longer.As for employers, they have built everything from thriving construction businesses to high-tech apps.It is not going to be beyond them to install plastic screens in the office, and nor are Lisa in marketing and Phil in accounts going to make like Professor Pantsdown in the filing cupboard.Are we prepared to trust our fellow Brits, take that risk and allow the next generation a better chance to succeed Even some of those in the highest at-risk groups will acknowledge we cannot live in economic shutdown forever.Even the boffins at Oxford know a vaccine will take months,not years.AndTikTok-ing millennials are not exactly winning much sympathy, what about the parents of young kids Anybody looking after children at home right now knows full well their productivity is close to zero.They need schools and nurseries open, too.Britain’s most dynamic cities and companies are being driven by the young, from the video game industry in Dundee to the start-up hubs of Shoreditch.They have had a decade of flatlining wages, a housing crisis and now the corona crash. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: tougher border checks arrivals uk after lockdown
story: TOUGHER border checks could be brought in after lockdown which may include a -day period in quarantine for all arrivals at UK borders.Boris Johnson will set out plans for gradually loosening parts of the lockdown in a speech on Sunday while tightening others, including border checks.A possible -day quarantine for everyone entering the UK will be extended to Brit citizens, although it may not be brought in straight away.Those arriving at UK borders may be forced to follow the same guidance as those within the country, such as being told to install the Covid- tracking app when it is rolled out.One official told the Financial Times: Whatever is in place for UK citizens you can expect to be in place for those arriving in the UK.Until now, passengers on regular commercial flights have been free to enter Britain without temperature checks or having to self-isolate.In most cases they have simply received leaflets detailing information on symptoms.Home Office figures revealed that around million people were let into Britain without any screening as coronavirus spread across the world.Only  travellers were made to self-isolate after entering the UK on four evacuation flights from Wuhan, China, where the virus originated, and Tokyo.They arrived in January and February and were taken to specialist facilities in Milton Keynes and Merseyside.But between January  and the March  lockdown, tens of thousands jetted in from bug-ravaged countries including Spain and Italy.Labour MP Stephen Doughty said the figures beggar belief.He added: That many of these people likely arrived and travelled onwards across the UK with little or no adherence to social distancing and with no checks or protections at the border is deeply disturbing.America banned inward travel from China and Europe to control the outbreak but no such measures were imposed by the UK.It came as Hungarian low-cost airline Wizz Air prepared to resume commercial flights on Friday, sparking fears others will follow suit.Passengers must wear a face covering and will be kept away from others as they fly.Meanwhile, Gatwick Airport called for travellers to take virus tests  hours before take-off once lockdown is over.A government spokesman said yesterday: Our approach to tackling coronavirus is, and has always been, driven by the latest scientic and medical advice, and procedures at the border have been strictly following the latest government guidance throughout.The scientic advice showed that placing restrictions at the border would not have had a signicant impact on the spread of the virus in the UK.More than , people have now died in hospitals, care homes and the wider community after testing positive for coronavirus in the UK, up  from the day before.Official figures indicate the number of deaths is signicantly higher.Coronavirus lockdown measures could start being eased from Monday, with Brits set to be allowed picnics in parks, unlimited exercise and some sports.Pub and cafe gardens could also open in an easing of lockdown restrictions. But people must still stay two metres from each other.The small relaxation from the coronavirus lockdown is the first of many that the PM plans to roll out week by week.Further loosening of the lockdown is expected later in May.Get Britains best-selling newspaper delivered to your smartphone or tablet each day - find out more.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: hayfever may be in the mind
story: A new study found that some people suffer from allergic reactions even when there is no pollen in the air and that they could in fact be having placebo responses.The study, published in the journal Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences in the US, suggests that someones symptoms might be caused by being in a place where they have previously been exposed to pollen.Dr Luciana Besedovsky, from Hard Medical School and the University of Tübingen, said an allergic response can be triggered even in the absence of allergens by simply reencountering the environmental context in which an allergen was previously administered.For the study, researchers recruited  men and administered triggers such as birch pollen and grass - all common allergies for people who suffer from hayfever - through a nasal spray.To determine whether their reactions were genuine or in fact part of a placebo effect, the group were asked toand carry out the experiment again.However, this time they were given a harmless nasal spray of salt water, but were told that there was a  per cent chance that it contained pollen.For some, simply being in the same room where they had originally been exposed to pollen did spur a reaction.Experts noted a rise in an enzyme known as tryptase, which is produced at a higher level during hay fever as the immune system kicks in.They then wanted to test whether a similar reaction could be triggered by a smell.The group were asked to snf an almond-scented chemical before being blasted with pollen.Scientists then asked them to repeat the experiment again at a later stage and noted that the scent triggered mild hay fever symptoms, such as sneezing, in some - even though there was no pollen around anymore.Dr Besedovsky, first author of the study, said: Our findings suggestsomeone goes to a place where they usually have hayfever, like a park with lots of trees, they might have an allergic reaction.This might happen outside of pollen season because they have been mentally conditioned to associate that park with hayfever.She added that while she is not claiming that people with hayfever make up the condition, it’s clear that there is a clear link between how the immune system responds to certain cues from the body.The academic also suspected that sleep may help people store a memory which links an allergic reaction to a place.To test this theory, half of the participants were asked to stay awake all night after the first experiment.For those who had a good nights sleep, their tryptase levels only rose the second time after originally being exposed to the pollen.However, most of the group had a rise in the enzyme when smelling the almond-scented chemical - regardless of whether or not they had slept.Dr Besedovsky said: These findings have important implications for understanding the often observed placebo allergic responses occurring in the absence of allergens.In conclusion to her findings, she said that sleep may actually be a contributor to the aggregation of allergies.All participants enrolled in the test were not found to have any sleep disturbances before they began the trial.She stated that people may have been mentally conditioned to associate a park with hayfever, therefore spurring on symptoms.In the UK, around  million people are affected by hay fever with the pollen seasons typically kicking off in late March or early April.The pollen count for this week across most of the county is at a moderate level, except in the north and Scotland where some areas will see high pollen concentrations.Meanwhile, as the coronavirus pandemic in the UK continues, hayfever sufferers have also been growing concerned about their symptoms, some of which can be mistaken for the virus.The two main symptoms of coronavirus are a high fever and a new continuous cough, whereas people suffering with hayfever will not have a high temperature and will not usually have aches and pains, another symptom of the virus.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: lockdown when see family social bubbles

title: ve day look back incredible
story: VE Day: Look back at incredible wartime cartoons by Mirror legend Philip ZecMirror war cartoonist Philip Zec captured the glory and evil and the Second World War, in artwork which was at times biting and hilarious satire, at other times exceptionally moving. He famously depicted the day Britain and allies handed victory and peace back to EuropeShareCommentsByTony Donnelly:,  MAY NewsHere You Are! Dont Lose It Again! May  A wounded British soldier emerges from the ruins of a devastated landscape.In his hand is an olive branch with a label carrying the message “Victory and peace in Europe”.Below him the caption reads: “Here you are! Don’t lose it again!”This was how the Daily Mirror’s legendary war cartoonist Philip Zec marked VE Day in .The stunning image was the last of more than , Zec wartime cartoons. They earned him a reputation as the people’s cartoonist, boosting morale here and infuriating the Nazis.Zec was Jewish, one of  children of a Russian immigrant. After he joined the Mirror in  aged , he fearlessly criticised fascism.A  cartoon showing Hitler eating Christmas dinner alone enraged German propaganda minister Joseph Goebbels.Zec recalled: “Some days later, we were sent a copy of a German newspaper in which they described me as ‘this filthy lying hyena scum’.The article went on to say that amongst the first dozen people to be shot when they arrived in London would be me”After the war, Nazi documents showed Zec, who died in , was indeed on an invasion “hitlist”. But on VE Day, he had the last laugh.September : Shortly after Britain declares war, Germany and Russia carve up the corpse of Poland. German Murderer: Its all right - hes dead now! And we can STILL take it!  of July : Churchill hands Nazis aticket to Berlin after Blitz fails. Many Unhappy Returns!  of December : American isolationism lies dead as the Japanese attack Pearl Harbour. The First American Casualty  of March : Black marketeers undermining the war effort have blood on their hands. Are YOUR hands clean   of June : Iconic image of shipwrecked sailor captioned The True Price of Petrol  of July : Montgomerys th Army defeats Rommel at El Alamein. Egypt Is Within Our Grasp!  of June : Monty  of April : Tribute to the courage of our Merchant Navy. Praise the Men Who Bring the Ammunition  of August : Grim Reaper joins RAF raid in Germany in cartoon captioned The Debt-Collector.  of April : Hitler tries to guess Allied invasion date. Zec correctly predicted June  - top right. S-stop S-Saying S-saying W-when!  of June : Allies hand Nazis their bill on D-Day. A cross-party group of MPs and peers, backed by a leading charity, fears a lack of checks on some businesses could pave the way for workers to be exploited. They have written to Home Secretary Priti Patel calling for labour inspectors to be classed as essential workers so scrutiny can continue during the Covid- lockdown.Lucila Granada, chief executive of charity Focus on Labour Exploitation, said: “Many low-paid workers are losing their jobs and urgently seeking new income desperation will prevent them from saying ‘no’ to abusive conditions, making inspection even more imperative than ever before.“Without this in place, we may see a surge in modern slavery cases over the coming months.”Nearly  politicians, including Labour, Lib Dem, Conservative, SNP, DUP and Alliance Party MPs, have written to Ms Patel, Business Secretary Alok Sharma and Safeguarding Minister Victoria Atkins demanding action. Their letter says: “Given the heightened risks of exploitation during this crisis, it is vital that enforcement agencies are able to conduct labour inspections and act to prevent exploitation.“The Government has rightly recognised that workers in food production are critical to the coronavirus response, but it must also include the people who ensure that they have safe, legal working conditions.”The letter warns that “widespread job losses and hoursapos reductions for those in low-paid work are being reported by frontline services”. It fears sacked staff will be “unable to turn down job offers with abusive or exploitative conditions, as this will mean a choice between affording basic living costs and facing destitution”. The signatories add: “Over time and left unchecked, this is likely to lead to a spike in modern slavery offences as trafficking gangs and others exploit these workers’ predicament.” The letter calls for workplace inspectors to be given enough personal protective equipment to carry out their roles – and for extra cash “to conduct preventative campaigns and monitoring, especially in high-risk sectors”.Ms Granada added: “Labour inspectors play a crucial role in keeping our workplaces and essential workers safe during these dficult times. “The failure to include them as ‘essential workers’ is an oversight that must be rectied immediately. “Our research has found that workers are already experiencing pandemic-related abuses. “This includes refusal of entitlements to sick pay and forcing people with symptoms to go to work who should be self-isolating to protect their own and the public health.” Lib Dem home affairs spokeswoman Christine Jardine, who organised the letter, said: “It’s absolutely vital that we recognise that the coronavirus crisis is leaving the most vulnerable in our communities at risk.

Research by charity Mind found nearly a quarter of people have not been able to access mental health services in the last two weeks. Almost a quarter of people who tried to access mental health support in the past fortnight had failed to get any help – facing cancelled appointments, dficulty getting through to their GP or Community Mental Health Team, being turned away by crisis services and issues accessing digital alternatives. One of those sufferers is Emily Nuttall, , a student and volunteer from St Peter Port in Guernsey, who has not had face-to-face therapy for nearly two months, after the sessions were suspended. She has been seeking help for her mental health since , after suffering from anorexia as well as anxiety, depression and self-harm. Miss Nuttall had been attending three therapy sessions a week since July last year, and fears she will relapse and end up in hospital without them. It takes me a long time to trust people and be open and honest, she said. Itaposs like taking a plaster off the wound and leaving it open and having nothing to close it. Itaposs frightening for me because there have been periods in the past few weeks that have been very dficult to deal with alone. Miss Nuttall last attended a face-to-face appointment at the beginning of March, but had to self-isolate shortly before the UK went into lockdown on March . She has had to rely on other people to pick up prescriptions and has arranged phone consultations with her psychologist once a week. Miss Nuttall has sought help from charities such as Mind and Beat, which have helped her cope with mental health problems during the crisis. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe UK has been in lockdown for six weeks. Hundreds of people are still dying each day from coronavirus. But now that weaposre past the peak, Boris Johnson will lay out a roadmap on Sunday  May for how lockdown will be eased. He will change very little immediately - and wonapost end lockdown in one go. But he suggested some changes will take effect from Monday  May. And in the long term, his plan will give us a clearer picture of what the UK will look like over the coming months in a new, coronavirus-scarred world. Schools and outdoor activities are set to resume within weeks, while pubs and restaurants look doomed to stay closed for months. Meanwhile the furlough scheme will be wound down after June, fines for breaching lockdown will rise, and you could be told to cover your face in public. So what will reopen, what will stay shut - and how will your everyday le change Weaposve explained the timeline and all the main proposals below.for the Mirror Politics newsletter at www.mirror email -at .am to navigate the day ahead.When will lockdown end The Prime Minister will lay out his roadmap for ending lockdown on Sunday  May - and he says some measures will be lted as early as Monday  Maywe possibly can. A minister will also address the House of Commons on Monday  May. But lockdown will not end all in one go. Immediate measures on Monday are likely to be only very minor and we donapost know yet what theyaposll be.Experts say some closures or social distancing will last until , when weaposre likely to have a vaccine. Cabinet minister Michael Gove warned: Ultimately, unless and until we have a vaccine, then I suspect we’re going to have to live with some degree of constraint because of the nature of the virus. Meanwhile, the legal date to review the lockdown is Thursday  May. That review will keep restrictions in place - but no detail will be announced on that day.  Will we be given specic dates  This seems unlikely. The Irish government has spelt out five phases each with a target date between May and August. But while Downing Street hasnapost denied using phases, they probably wonapost have a specic date. Instead Boris Johnson’s spokesman said: “What we’ll have to do as we make changes is monitor the impact those changes are having upon the R rate in particular. “And once we have that information, we’ll obviously be able to judgeand when we’re in a position to go further.”  What will the roadmap talk about It will spell out how the lockdown changes in phases over time. It may have a traffic light system spelling out what you can and canapost do as restrictions lt. The plan could also drop the governmentaposs stay at home branding in favour of a more subtle message. But it will also make clear that the UK is not ing to business as usual.Some restrictions will be eased, but others - like fines for breaches - will be made harsher than they are now. While people are put back on public transport and in some workplaces, there will be strict social distancing to keep people two metres apart. People are likely to be advised to cover their faces, and will be told to use an NHS phone app that alerts youyouaposve come into close contact with the virus.  How does the R number, apostest, track and traceapos and five tests come into all this  The aposRapos number is the average number of people infected by each Covid- carrier. It has to be low enough for each stage of the roadmap to begin. Currently R is between . and . because so many people are out of contact with each other. Every time you relax a lockdown rule, R rises again. Ministers say they wonapost do anything that pushes the R number back above . The UK must also pass five tests before easing lockdown:The NHS is able to cope A sustained fall in deaths New infections dropping enough Adequate testing and PPE No risk of a second peak that overwhelms NHSTo help pass all these tests there is a apostest, track and traceapos strategy planned for launch at the middle of May. It will mean downloading an NHS app which tells youyouaposve been near a Covid- carrier - and ensuring you isolate quicklyyouaposre put at risk to stop it spreading further. More on this below. So what will the plan say   Schools Schools will reopen in a phased way - with some year groups likely to go back first while others are told to remain at home.Boris Johnson has signalled he wants primary schools to be the first to , and it is likely that Year  will be the first to . Years  and  would then be the first back in secondary schools, according to one plan. Priority could also be put on pupils with special educational needs. Teachers need time to put social distancing in place, including reorganising classrooms to keep children  metres apart. Sources suggest this will begin as early as June . No declined to sayall pupils will be back before September. Universities Arts students will be the last to , with students of medicine, dentistry and veterinary science prioritised in the autumn, according to the Sunday Times. Thirty-three universities are working on a contingency plan to fast-track students of the key sciences back to campus.  Public transport The number of trains will slowly rise as lockdown eases, to avoid overcrowding. Hand sanitiser and one-way systems would be placed on the network, with spacing at s and bus stops “clearly marked out” to keep people two metres apart. New timetables will be introduced as planned in May, even though trains will not run to them straight away. Firms would be urged to stagger workersapos start times to spread out the rush out. But London mayor Sadiq Khan has warned capacity could be overwhelmed. A double decker London bus would have to have just  passengers. Meanwhile the government has hinted at more support for Cycle to Work, a tax break scheme where you can buy a bicycle over a year through your employer.  Workplaces and working from home Workplaces would have floor markings to ensure people are two metres apart, according leaked draft guidance. The guidance could also recommend staggered arrival times and breaks, fewer people in lts and regular deep cleaning. According to BuzzFeed News, other draft measures for workplaces include:Providing additional parking or bike racks Having more entrances into the workplace Alternatives to touch-based security devices such as keypads Washing unorms on site rather than at home Reducing maximum occupancy for lts, providing hand sanitiser for the operation of lts and encouraging use of stairs Introducing more one-way flow routes through buildings Reviewing layouts to allow staff to work further apart from each otherBut workers would in some cases be allowed to sit less than two metres apart - despite the risk being  to  times higher at one metre than two metres. Not all workers would go back to the officethey donapost need to. Government advisors have previously said working from home could become the new normal until thereaposs a vaccine for coronavirus.The furlough scheme At the moment, .m workers are having their wages paid by the state - up to % or £, a month. Chancellor Rishi Sunak has warned this is not sustainable because it costs as much as the NHS. The furlough scheme runs in full up to the end of June and will then be wound down.Officials appear to be looking at cutting the amount to workers and the self-employed or limiting it only to certain sectors. This has sparked fears some will lose out. The future of the furlough scheme wonapost be announced on Sunday. Sources said it would be in the week or two weeks after the PMaposs address on Sunday.Picnics, golf course, tennis and going outdoors People will be allowed to exercise more than once a day, drive to the countryside and have picnics, according to the Mail on Sunday. And the Daily Mail claims golf courses, tennis courts and fishing lakes will reopen from June too. Youaposd still have to be with members of your own household only, and keep two metres away from other groups.  No has not confirmed these reports.But ministers and scientists have repeatedly said outdoor activities are less risky than those indoors - indicating theyaposll be the first to be allowed back.  Supermarkets Supermarkets would doubtless keep many of the social distancing measures theyaposve already put in place. And opening hours could be increased on Sunday to reduce overcrowding. Boris Johnson has said heaposs looking at relaxing Sunday trading laws to reduce queues on the weekend.  Building sites Building sites were never told to close under lockdown guidance - as long as two metres could be kept between workers. So the government is expected to make a renewed push for people toto work there. Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick said because the risk of the virus outdoors is lower than indoors, there’s “more scope” for some jobs outside. He added: “Thereaposs more scope for people ing to work on building sites for example, or more outdoor leisure activities than is likely to be the case for indoor ones.”  aposBubblesapos of up to  people People could meet small bubbles of their friends and family under one idea to ease the coronavirus lockdown. Nicola Sturgeon said the Scottish government was looking at the proposal as one possible way to relax restrictions on peopleaposs movement in the future. But she warnedthe idea does happen, itaposs got to be the same people day-to-day, week-to-week to prevent Covid- being passed on more widely. That means people would have to choose one bubble of friends or family - and stick with them, while continuing not to meet other people they love. Reports later said the idea was one being mulled by the UK government. But itaposs not set in stone.  Fines for breaching lockdown The government is considering raising the penalty for defying lockdown from £ to £ for a first offence. The fines would then double for each offence after that, just as they do already. And the maximum fine would rise from just under £, at the moment to £,. A senior government source did not deny these figures, reported by the Sunday , were under consideration. Covering your face The government hasnapost made a final decision on whether to ask people to cover their face in public. However, some kind of face covering advice is widely expected after Boris Johnson covering oneaposs face in some situations would be a useful tool. Itaposs understood thatface coverings are required, they wonapost be masks. The government doesnapost want to cause a shortage in personal protective equipment that should be available to the NHS. But coverings like a scarf could be recommended. And the government would provide guidance on what kind of material you can make such a covering from. Itaposs important that people donapost end up fiddling with their face covering in a way that means theyaposre actually creating more risk, by continually touching their face.  Using a new app A new contact tracing app is expected to launch in around mid-May after trials on the Isle of Wight this week. The app, which is voluntary, will use Bluetooth to track when people have come into close contact with someone who, now or later, tests positive for coronavirus. It will urge someone who’s been in contact with a virus carrier to get tested and to isolate themselvesnecessary. It is part of the crucial “test, track and trace” strategy that is needed before the UK-wide lockdown can be relaxed. The idea is that this would allow society to partially reopen while keeping the virus at bay and sick people in isolation. For it to work properly, at least % or so of the population need to download it. It will be paired with an army of , human contact tracers to follow up on those who need further attention, or those who don’t download the app.  Arriving in the UK Ministers are actively looking at quarantining people who arrive into the UK once lockdown begins to ease. Nothing is confirmed, but reports have suggested people will be asked to isolate themselves for two weeks. If so, this would be a major blow to the airline industry and render most holidays to Britain pointless. Transport Secretary Grant Shapps told the BBC: I think it’s important... that we ensure the sacrices in the sense of social distancing that we’re asking the British people to make are matched by anybody who comes to this country. So I am actively looking at these issues right now. So that when we have infection rates within the country under control, weaposre not importing. Local lockdowns The government is considering new wave of local lockdown restrictions later this year to stop new spikes of coronavirus in their tracks. At the moment, officials are focused on easing the lockdown at the same pace across the UK - to move as one nation in the Covid- crisis. But itaposs understood officials are looking at changing that approachthere is a rapid new second outbreak of the virus, which needs quick action to be halted. A government source said: If you were to see worrying increases of transmission happening in regions, then you would want to move quickly to try and stop those.  Pubs, grassroots sport, mass gatherings and other venues Pubs will be the last places to reopen as lockdown is eased, the Government has confirmed. Likewise, ministers have indicated that mass gatherings will be among the last things to reopen. But some local cricket and grassroots football could– as long as spectators can stay in the open air. Deputy Chief Medical Officer Dr Jenny Harries said: “Outdoor environments are safer. Butyou go with a load of friends and sit in a pub… that’s not a good thing to do.” And Communities Secretary Robert Jenrick told the No coronavirus update: “Transmission is signicantly less outdoors than indoors.” Meanwhile hairdressers and nail bars could remain shut for six months, sources told The Sun. A aposone UKapos approach Scotland and Wales have repeatedly set out plans ahead of, or slightly dferently to, the rest of the UK government. And itaposs true that the Scottish and Welsh governments have control over areas like schools and care homes. However, ministers have also stressed they want to keep the whole of the UK moving in the same way at the same time. And the government has distanced itself from claims that worst-hit regions, like London and the West Midlands, could have dferent rules to the countryside. NHS services Some routine operations and fertility treatment have already been restored as hospital inpatients fall for several weeks in a row. However, itaposs not yet clear when other services - including ENT therapies and dentistry, where staff are particularly at risk of transmission - will continue.

Ministers are encouraging stay-cations, but it is not clearjourneys to areas such as the Lake District, Cornwall or Devon will be permitted by July and August. Cumbria’s director of public health Colin Cox has said there was a risk of a second wave of infections as lockdown in the Lakes was “fraying at the edges”.Hotels, caravan parks and BBs are all still shut, and in a recent Downing Street press conference, a business owner in Cornwall asked Boris Johnson how tourism would be managed.He said: “We have to get your business going again, to get tourism going again. “But we can’t allow such a big influx of tourists as to create a second spike, a second wave of the disease.”Cabinet Minister Michael Gove told MPs that “at the moment and for some time to come” people should not travel to visit popular seaside resorts.Some UK hotels might stay shut for a yearthey cannot open for summer. Patricia Yates, of Visit Britain, warned that for many hotels it would not be worth openingthey were restricted to less than % capacity due to social distancing measures. She said: “The normal pattern is businesses make their money in July and August then make do for the rest of the year. Germany and Italy have both announced their citizens should be able to have summer breaks abroad. An alliance has been created between Australia, Austria, Israel, the Czech Republic, Denmark, Greece and New Zealand to make travel between them easier. Austrian Chancellor Sebastian Kurz said: “Our nations reacted early and forcefully, and now we’re in a better place.” In Spain, the Balearic Islands’ tourism minister Iago Negueruela singled out Britain for its response to the virus, suggesting it had handicapped chances of holidays in Ibiza, Majorca or Menorca. German tourism commissioner Thomas Bareiss said citizens should be able to travel to neighbouring countries “that can be reached by car”, such as Holland, Austria, France, Poland and Belgium. He said: “I would not yet write off other regions in Europe, such as the Balearic Islands or the Greek islands. “I hope that, given the good numbers, we will be able to relax the restrictions in four to eight weeks.” Latvia, Lithuania and Estonia will open their borders to each others’ citizens from May . Lithuania’s PM Saulius Skvernlis said: “All three Baltic states have properly contained the spread of the coronavirus, and we trust each others’ health systems.” Travel between Britain and France by ferry or Eurotunnel is ing, but people must prove they have a family or professional reason for crossing the Channel or they live permanently in France to continue the journey on the other side. This is expected to continue for some time yet after President Emmanuel Macron warned his citizens that it was “too soon to say whether we can take holidays”.

Researchers had feared that there were more than one type of SARS-CoV-, the virus that causes the killer disease, circulating - with one more deadly than the other. But scientists from the Medical Research Council-University of Glasgow Centre for Virus Researchhave branded this unfounded. Although thousands of mutations have been found, researchers say the numbers are still relatively low, which is grounds for optimism. Dr Oscar MacLean, from the CVR, said: By analysing the extensive genetic sequence iation present in the genomes of the SARS-CoV- virus, the evolutionary analysis shows why these claims that multiple types of the virus are currently circulating are unfounded.to get the Mirror’s daily coronavirus briefing email at  mirror email  -after the press conference every evening. It is important people are not concerned about virus mutations - these are normal and expected as a virus passes through a population. However, these mutations can be useful as they allow us to track transmission history and understand the historic pattern of global spread. Viruses, including the one causing Covid-, naturally accumulate mutations - or changes - in their genetic sequence as they spread through populations. Scientists said most of these changes will have no effect on the biology of the virus or the aggressiveness of the disease they cause.  It was reported earlier this year that scientists had found two or three strains of SARS-CoV- circulating in the population, evidenced by certain mutations that had been detected. However extensive analysis by the team found these detected mutations are unlikely to have any al signicance, and, importantly, do not represent dferent virus types. The centreaposs CoV-GLUE resource tracks SARS-CoV-aposs amino acid replacements, insertions and deletions, which have been observed in samples from the pandemic. To date the database has catalogued , mutations in the pandemic.  Scientists said that while this may sound like a lot of change, it is a relatively low rate of evolution for a virus that has ribonucleic acidas its genetic material. They expect more mutations will continue to accumulate as the pandemic continues. Most observed mutations would be expected to have no, or minimal, consequence to the virusaposs biology, however tracking these changes can help scientists better understand the pandemic and how Covid- is spreading in the community. The study is published in Virus Evolution and the work was funded by the Medical Research Council. Elsewhere, other scientists say they have identied a new coronavirus strain that has become dominant worldwide.The researchers have been tracking changes to the spike of the virus that gives it its distinctive shape. They warn that in addition to making it grow faster, the mutation may make people vulnerable to a second infection after a first bout with the disease. Bosses at First West of England have begun to block off seats on on the  bus route and will ensure that people sit apart.  First Bus runs services around the UK, and is one of the largest operators outside London - providing about a fth of the nationaposs bus services - amounting to  million passenger journeys last year. story: NewsHeroic schoolboy, , jumps into canal and saves toddler from drowningQuick thinking Ryley Ferguson was walking his two dogs when he spotted -month-old Reggie Hampton sinking to the bottom of the canal near his home in Knottingley, West YorkshireShareCommentsByJeremy Armstrong:,  MAY Updated:,  MAY NewsRylan Ferguson, , holding little Reggie after saving him from drowning in a canal " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailA teenage boy has been hailed a hero after jumping into a canal to save a toddler from drowning. Ryley Ferguson, , was on his daily walk with his two dogs when he spotted the -month-old in the water near his home in Knottingley, W Yorks. The quick-thinking teenager threw his shoes and coat off to grab the toddler as he sank to the bottom of the canal. Now Rebecca Hampton, , the relieved mum of rescued boy Reggie Johnson, has hailed Ryley as her ‘ Angel’....and is backing calls by locals to give him a Mirror Pride of Britain award. Ryley did not hesitate when he knew Reggie’s le was on the line.to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at  www.mirror email “I’m just so happy I was there and managed to e in, in time to save him,” he said. “I didn’t have time to think, I was just on my walk with my dogs when I saw him fall in. I took my shoes and coat off - it was pure instinct at that point. It all happened in a split second. Suddenly I was at the bottom of the canal and managed to grab him. I was pretty calm but the water was so cold,my heart was racing. “In the end all that mattered was that he was okay. If I walked by just thirty seconds later, he could have died. I had to save him.” Ryley struggled to get out of the canal as he was holding the toddler, but two men raced to pull him clear as he shouted for help. Once they got out, little Reggie began to cry but Ryley says the tot calmed down after he reassured him, saying, ‘don’t worry, I got you’. Rebecca was reunited with her son just moments later. She had been working in the garden, and her adventurous little boy had wandered into the canal which runs behind their home.  The single mum-of-two, who also has daughter Petal, four, says the families now share a “bond for le” and Reggie will grow up knowing what Ryley did. “I keep saying Ryley is ourangel, he saved my boy and saved my le,” she added. “Reggie will grow up knowing who Ryley is and what he’s done. He’s our superhero.” A neighbour had rushed into our house and said Reggie was in the canal. “The world stopped for me at that moment, I was in complete shock,” Rebecca recalled. “I started shouting for him, it must have been a couple minutes at most but it felt like an eternity. I can’t tell you the relief when I saw my beautul boy. I can’t thank Ryley enough, I gave him a card with some money but no money in the world will ever cover what he’s done for me.”  Rebecca added that her son had suffered no ill effects - though she washed him in the sink at first to avoid the trauma of a bath. He is so fast for his age, I was busy in the garden so I did not see him, she said. I cannot thank Ryley enough, I nominated him for Pride of Britain, I think he really does deserve it. Ryley’s mum, care home cook Amy, was at work at the time of the rescue and couldn’t believe what happened. Amy, who is married to Michael, would love to see her son get a Pride of Britain award. It is lovely that so many people have nominated him, she said. Weaposre very proud of him. He saw Reggieaposs feet disappearing in the water. It is a good job he saw him, any later and they would not have had any idea where he was.

story: NewsKate Middleton shares powerful photos that capture nations mood in coronavirus crisisThe Duchess of Cambridge, herself a keen photographer, wants the public to share photos representing three themes - Helpers and Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts of KindnessShareCommentsByRussell Myers:,  MAY NewsKate Middleton is calling on photographers to capture the nations mood" to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. Sometimes they’ll include recommendations for other related newsletters or services we offer. OurPrivacy Noticeexplains more about how we use your data, and your rights. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailThe Duchess of Cambridge wants the public to share their photos which capture the nation’s mood during the Covid crisis. Accomplished amateur snapper Kate has chosen five images she believes represent photography project Hold Still’s three core themes – Helpers and Heroes, Your New Normal and Acts of Kindness. She said: “We’ve all been struck by some of the incredible images we’ve seen which have given us an insight into the experiences and stories of people across the country. “Hold Still aims to capture a portrait of the nation, the spirit of the nation, what everyone is going through. “Photographs reflecting resilience, bravery, kindness – all those things that people are experiencing.” to get the Mirroraposs biggest and best stories delivered straight to your inbox at  www.mirror emailKate’s choices include a heartbreaking shot of intensive care nurse Aimee Gould’s face covered in red marks from PPE after a -hour sht treating sick patients at Doncaster and Bassetlaw Teaching Hospital. Aimee, who shared the selfie online, wrote: “This is the face going through hell. This is the face full of pressure damage from wearing PPE for almost  hours a day. This is the face of someone who hasn’t seen their own family for nearly a month. “This is the face of someone who holds your dying family member’s hand, so they’re never alone.” Another snap shows Ray and Theresa Cossey, both , in lockdown in Norfolk and their great-grandchildren Florence, three, and Edith, one, trying to touch them through glass. The moving snap was shared on Twitter by ITV weatherman Chris Page, who wrote: “This is the most adorable thing I’ve seen so far today from a friend of mine!”Another of the Duchess’s choices is a sweet picture which was posted by West Midlands Ambulance Service showing an adorable five-year-old called Eadee with her face covered in multi-coloured paint. Her mum Katie said “she wanted to be a rainbow in the shape of a love heart” to thank brave NHS workers.  Kate also selected images of Jack Dodsley, , dancing with a worker dressed in a protective mask at Newfield Nursing Home, Sheffield, and a masked worker carrying NHS scrubs being made last month in a manufacturing site in North London. Hold Still is being run in conjunction with the National Portrait Gallery, which Kate is a patron of.She will launch the project on ITV’s This Morning today and submissions can be made via npg.org.uk.Images can be from phones or cameras and each will be assessed on the emotion and experience it conveys rather than its photographic quality or technical expertise.  Participants are encouraged to write a short statement describing why their photograph should be selected for display. The closing date for entries is June . The top  will be part of a final exhibition which will be released digitally at first and potentially become a physical exhibition in the future. Kate, , is a confident and skilled photographer, regularly releasing her own photographs to mark her children’s birthdays in recent years. A senior palace source said: “The Duchess has been inspired by many of the amazing feats accomplished by so many people that have brought Britain together. “The aim of the project is to bring together an unofficial national archive of the crisis, what has touched our everyday lives, the heroes behind the stories and images.  “The Duchess’s choices merely act as inspiration for the categories – anyone can enter and the aim is to get as many people involved as possible. “The hope is it will create a unique photographic portrait of the people of our nation as we hold still for the good of others, and celebrate those who have continued so we can stay safe.” Kensington Palace said the aim was to “capture the spirit, the mood, the hopes, the fears and the feelings of the nation as we continue to deal with the outbreak”.

story: NewsMum-of-two angel whisperer who celebs have on speed dial for psychic readingsClaire Stone, who says she can see and speak to angels, grew up in poverty and uncertainty in Merseyside. Now the -year-old gives tarot card readings to stars from The Real Housewives Of Cheshire and TOWIEShareCommentsByDebbi Marco:,  MAY NewsClaire Stone is the psychic to the stars " to FREE email alerts from Mirror - daily newsSubscribeWhen you subscribe we will use the information you provide to send you these newsletters. You can unsubscribe at any time.Thank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee ourprivacy noticeInvalid EmailGrowing up, Claire Stone’s family thought she was talking to the devil. But now she uses her psychic abilities to give advice to the rich and famous. When Claire Stone’s phone buzzes with a message from model Tanya Bardsley or TV presenter Lizzie Cundy, she’s not surprised. Her contacts list is packed with stars from The Real Housewives Of Cheshire and The Only Way Is Essex. They rely on Claire to provide them with psychic readings and answers to their le ­questions. And when she’s not helping celebrities with their burning issues, Claire is teaching others how to ­connect with spirit guides through her workshops and courses. It’s a far cry from the poverty and uncertainty the -year-old faced when she grew up in Merseyside. From the age of two she lived with her mother and grandparents, after her dad left. Her grandparents died in her early teens, and when her mum became unwell Claire ended up becoming a young carer for her two-year-old twin sisters. “When I was  I was left to raise my sisters,” says Claire, who still lives in St Helens, Merseyside, with her husband John and daughters who are  and eight. “I was out of school looking after them. But I also had agoraphobia, which meant I struggled to go outside. “Sometimes social services would bring us beans and sacks of spuds, but I really think we slipped through the net.” Despite her mental health problems and unstable home le, Claire did have one thing she could rely on – her gt of talking to angels. “I’ve always been able to see angels but it wasn’t until I was about six that I realised my cousins didn’t have the same experiences as me,” reveals Claire. But her family were strict Christians who attended church every week.  “The vicar would say it was the devil’s work,” says Claire. As she grew older she struggled mentally. “I thought I was cursed because I had such a hideous le.” It was then, Claire says, she started to connect with an angel called Archangel Ariel. Ariel would come to Claire at night and she would hear her voice as a thought. “She started telling me how to cure my anxiety,” says Claire. She also had a deck of tarot cards and at  started doing readings for her friends. Now Claire has built her career around giving readings and teaching others to connect with their angel and spirit guides. “People often come because they are in two minds about relationships or careers. Linking rent to takings would save crisis-hit retailers vital money during tough trading periods, it is argued. Sean Mercer was  when he murdered the popular -year-old child who had just finished football practice in . Mercer was jailed in  and ordered to serve at least  years, meaning his earliest release date was , at the age of .He was a prominent member of the notorious Croxteth Crew gang, and is now attempting to reduce his jail term, Liverpool Echo reports.His lawyers are set to argue he should be entitled to a sentence reduction because he was a juvenile, aged , when he murdered Rhys nearly  years ago. Under law in England and Wales, juveniles are entitled to a review of their minimum tarf, halfway through their sentence, now applicable to Mercer given he has served  years. But Mercer was convicted and sentenced when he was , having become an adult, so his appeal may stand on shaky ground. Steve and Melanie Jones, Rhysapos parents, were alerted to a possible legal challenge by their sonaposs killer in recent months. Probation Service bosses asked them to compose a victim impact statement, detailing the devastation Merceraposs actions had caused, and why they objected to his latest jail bid. Their account was written and sent off, but the Jonesapos have not heard anything further. Steve told Liverpool Echo : Weaposre not happy Mercer is doing this.Heaposs got his sentence and he had a fair trial. Heaposs just trying to get out as soon as he can, he should serve his full -year tarf. You read certain things that Mercer is a changed person, but like the others in his gang have proved, theyaposve been in more trouble since Rhys was killed. I donapost think heaposs changed. He added: These updates about how one of them is trying to challenge things, it brings Rhysapos murder back to us all the time. Mel gets these phone calls and it takes her back to the car park when she went to find Rhys all those years ago. Once lodged, Merceraposs application would be heard at the High Court.  It is understood it is yet to be lodged, but those close to him have been working on the appeal, and it could be filed soon. If Merceraposs appeal was successful, he would still need to apply to the Parole Board to considerhe was fit to be released.  Mercer shot Rhys outside the Fir Tree pub in Croxteth Park before leaving the scene on his mountain bike and going on the run. His gang accomplice James Yates supplied the Smith and Wesson gun used to shoot Rhys before helping him to dispose of his bike, clothes and the firearm he gave him minutes before the murder. Last month, it was revealed how Yatesy had been released from jail, having served the  year sentence for possession of a firearm and assisting an offender. Mercer chose to run an -week trial at Liverpool Crown Court, denying the murder, but was found unanimously guilty. Mr Justice Irwin delivered withering sentencing remarks to him and his fellow gang members, explaining how they were not the soldiers they claimed to be. title: dundee united fc supporters foundation mark ogren
story: Dundee United fans are open to fresh talks with owner Mark Ogren over their proposed £, cash injection.Ogren cut ties with the Dundee United Supporters’ Foundationlast month when he publicly insisted he wouldn’t be dealing with them anymore.But the group have called on American businessman Ogren to consider a U-turn as they bid to invest in their club.Mal Brannigan – the United chief who had been in discussions with the organisation – left his post as managing director on Friday.The DUSF’s John Gibson said: “We would be happyMr Ogren wanted to get back round the table.“We’re still really hurt by this and feel as though we’ve been thrown under the bus.“We never understood why such a damaging statement was released but we just want the best for the club.“In our last conversation with Mal Brannigan, we made it clear that we hadn’t shut the door on anything.”In a statement issued on April , Ogren claimed the Tangerines could not agree to the conditions tied to potential DUSF investment and would be creating a new foundation themselves.He said: “After initially being told the organisation was there to assist our club with monies which have been raised throughout their membership, we as a board were not willing to fulfil the unreasonable demands of DUSF encompassing a requirement for shares and thereafter a secured loan.“This is particularly troublesome to us considering the size of the overall investment Scottand I have put into Dundee United FC and quite frankly goes against all the values that we have as owners and as a club.”The DUSF defended its proposals as “fair and reasonable”.They said: “Our objective was to protect our members’ interests whilst also enabling us to assist the club.“We have also had to ensure we discharge our duties as directors of a private company limited by guarantee by showing prudence and due diligence before recommending the release of a six-figure sum of members’ money.” months free access to our web and title: fan reaction spfl vote u turn john nelms
story: John Nelms says he understands the frustrations of Dundee fans after his voting U-turn saw Dundee United crowned Championship winners # but insists the decision was “for the best of the football club”.And he’s thanked “amazing” supporters who have already spent their hard-earned money on a season ticket for the next campaign despite not knowing when it will start or what it might look like.The Dens Park managing director was at the centre of the voting storm that engulfed Scottish football last month as the Dark Blues’ deciding vote swung from a ‘no’ to a ‘yes’ and allowed the SPFL’s resolution to end the   season in the lower leagues to pass.It also granted rivals United the league title and promotion to the Premiership. After an unclear club statement that later emerged to be Dundee’s notice of submitting a ‘yes’ vote, some Dark Blues fans reacted angrily to the decision.Askedhe understood the feelings of the supporters, Nelms told the Tele: “Absolutely. I don’t ever really say which way I vote, I give principles of what we’re doing and why we’re doing it.“The last daywe did a holding statement saying we’re not going to make a statement until we actually do something and then the next statement came out because we actually did something and voted.“But, people didn’t realise that we actually voted. So, we had to put out another statement.“You know how I am, I don’t talk about players# contracts, I don’t do things like that because I don’t think it’s appropriate at the time because you are negotiating. You can’t do that in the public eye because it’s not beneficial for the football clubyou do it that way.“We talked about it and I could see why the fans were concerned.“Honestly, I’m not surethe fans can see it or not but we are doing whatever we can do for the best of the football club, always. Not once in a while, not when it suits, always.“We will make decisions that might not be popular among the fans in the short-term but overall in the long-term it will benefit the football club. That’s the way we will run the business and I don’t think we’ve done anything but that. I’ll take the heat for it and that comes with the territory.”The club haven’t had any match income for over seven weeks due to the coronavirus shutdown.Nelms says Dundee are in a “stable position” but accepts there is no way of knowing what the future might hold.“At the moment, the way we have the business set up, with insurances and the way the“It is a new reality. Our business has changed from getting excited and ready for the next match to basically survival.“We are trying to prepare for when we come out of this but we don’t really know what is going to happen – we have nine dferent budget options for next year.“We don’t know when we are going to start playing again and that is the hard, frustrating part of it all.”Asked how much the club is losing per month, Nelms replied: “This is one of these things where I won’t talk about specic numbers.“Every club is going to be dferent – most clubs don’t have the insurance policies we have in place so they will be losing more than we will.“The government has really stepped in and helped out the mid-sized to lower-end clubs.“At the bigger clubs with the salaries the players are on, although the furlough helps, it doesn’t help a huge amount.“I would say Dundee Football Club and others around the size of our club are at a pucker point where it really helps us out and it helps out clubs below us but above it won’t help out as much.“We’re OK at the moment but we don’t know what is going to happen.”Despite not knowing when the next campaign will be, fans have already been putting money into the club by buying season tickets for  .An “amazing” gesture says Nelms.“You can’t thank people enough in a day and age like this where every day you are living basically day-to-day to see people step up and buy season tickets is amazing,” he added.“It’s incredible to see the number of people who have bought them with a big unknown going forward.“We will be playing football at some point in time, we just don’t know exactly when.“The fact they have faith in the club and desperately want to see their team is helpful – and also helps us build the team based on the support we have.“We know there are things that are way more important now than football butpeople want to dig in their pockets then great,not we’ll see you when we are all back together and have a good product on the park.” months free access to our web and ePaper pack including Premium articles.

title: lee wilkie mal brannigan dundee united
story: Mal Brannigan’s exit from Tannadice on Friday night was a surprise – for the first time in Mark Ogren’s reign there are some uncomfortable questions to answer.It did appear like a bolt out of the blue, Brannigan had been interviewed in this very paper just the day before he left his role as managing director.A sudden departure for a club’s managing director raises questions over what is going on behind the scenes.There are obvious issues there, evenwe don’t really know what’s brought about the decision to part company.The manner of the club in dealing with the Dundee United Supporters’ Foundation raised some suspicion a couple of weeks back.It came across as an extreme reaction to a fan group looking to hand over a serious sum of money they had raised.To blacklist them so publicly was a very strange move.That was the first time there had been anything other than positive news coming out of the club since the Ogrens took over.Brannigan’s departure coming so soon afterwards makes it dficult to think anything other than they are linked in some way.Like the rest of the fans, I am on the outside looking in.But it doesn’t seem like everything is as rosy behind the scenes as we’d been led to believe.That doesn’t mean there’s a scandal waiting to be uncovered but a bit of clarity from the club in what’s been going on would be good.Fallings out and disagreements behind the scenes tend to happen when things aren’t going so well on the pitch.That’s what has jarred so much about this past couple of weeks at United.The club are in such a good place, they’ve won the Championship and are gearing up for the Premiership next season.Money has been invested in the first team, the academy and certainly around the stadium.The Ogrens’ reign has been pretty much positive right the way through.The sort of questions this last fortnight has brought about will be unwanted ones from their point of view.It’s certainly not the kind of attention the Americans or those involved with running the club want or need right now.I just hope it’s not an indication there are problems at Tannadice.Until we hear more from the club, all United fans will be concerned about that scenario.Just like everyone , I was keen to hear John Nelms’ viewpoint on the SPFL voting farce last month.I thought he came out of the interview in the Tele very well.I agree with him that Dundee were stuck between a rock and a hard place – being third they would be unlikely to go up in any league reconstruction.Any benefit would be a longer-term thing where they’ll likely be in a good position for promotion to the Premiership in the new set-up.You could feel the frustration in Nelms from his quotes about the position he and Dundee had been left in by the SPFL.I actually felt quite bad for him over the way it had all been handled by the powers-that-be.You could tell he was holding back on what he thought of Inverness and the leaked WhatsApp messages, too!Nelms came across well and made a good point about Rangers – the vote didn’t even concern the Gers directly so why did the fans all go crazy at Dundee The football world never ceases to amaze.Tommy Wright did a great job at St Johnstone – consistently challenging despite not having the budget to really compete with the big boys.I have to say I found the timing of his departure from McDiarmid Park strange.Maybe he’d just had enough of battling away for so long.Technically this season isn’t even over yet. Maybe the shutdown just gave him enough time to think about his future.And the Northern Ireland manager’s gig is available…This week we’ll see what evidence Rangers have on the SPFL over the voting saga. I have to say I’m keen to see what they have – after all this time,it’s nothing major, they’ll be left with egg on faces. months free access to our web and ePaper pack including Premium articles.

title: aberdeen city council make donation to covid 19 support fund
story: Aberdeen City Council has agreed to donate £, to help with efforts to deal with impact of Covid-.Members of the urgent business committee backed the cash allocation from the local authority#s common good fund for the Aberdeen Covid- Emergency Hardship Fund.It followed a motion put forward by council co-leader Councillor Jenny Laing, which was approved unanimously by the committee.The emergency Covid- Hardship Fund was launched last week by The Lord Provost’s Charitable Trust in Aberdeen in partnership with The Seven Incorporated Trades of Aberdeen and Aberdeen City Council.The aim of the  fund is to raise much-needed cash for Aberdeen-based registered charities to help iniduals, families and communities across the city experiencing severe financial hardship as a direct result of the Covid- pandemic.City council co-leader Councillor Jenny Laing said: “Providing support to communities and the most vulnerable people within them has been at the heart of how Aberdeen City Council has responded to coronavirus since the lockdown started on March .“Today’s agreement by this council to donate £, from the common good fund to the Aberdeen Covid- Emergency Appeal, will enable registered charities in the city access crucial financial support to help iniduals, families and communities in desperate need as a result of the coronavirus.“By working together, we can ensure that those in need get the support they urgently require during these extraordinary times.”The Lord Provost of Aberdeen Barney Crockett, on behalf of the Lord Provost’s Charitable Trust said: “When the Common Good Fund was created  years ago in , it was for the purpose of using it to benefit the people and communities in Aberdeen.  Today’s announcement by Aberdeen City Council to donate £, from the Common Good Fund to go to this special Covid- Hardship Fund, is a wonderful excellent example of why the Common Good Fund exists.“Launched only last week the Covid- Hardship Fund got off to a flying start but I would urge businesses, associations and private iniduals to support this appeal and donate whatever they can now.  Together we can make a dference.” months free access to our web and title: my lockdown diary by elrick primary pupil corey stage
story: Hi, my name is Corey and I turned  during lockdown.I live in Westhill with my mum, dad and sister, who is seven.Lots of things have changed since my school Elrick Primary closed. Our teachers are putting up work and supporting us online. I have been reading more and trying hard at the work I have been given.My two favourite subjects are maths and art. My teacher has been giving my class riddles every day which are very fun but sometimes tricky. I really miss my friends and teacher. I can still talk to my friends through FaceTime and messages which I enjoy doing.My sister and I collected tadpoles from a local pond before lockdown. We have been watching them develop and are keeping a diary of their le cycle. During lockdown, me, my mum and sister have also been doing a lot more baking which has been fun.
